characters: BOBBY'S HOME OFFICE OFF THE KITCHEN
NEW GTX CORPORATE HEADQUARTERS BUILDING SITE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're GLIDING ABOVE an elegant silver coffee service, tra of cut fruit, bagels. Men and women in business attire ta notes at linen covered banquet tables, nurse coffees.

dialogues.speaker: STEVENS, (VO)
dialogues.text: ...we've reviewed our pipeline of some 500 projects and programs... The CAMERA MOVES ALONG the dais, placards set in front of slightly bored panel participants, behind them a banner a corporate logo announce: GTX Global Transportation System STEVENS (cont'd) ..-focusing on those with significant marketing opportunities and jettisoning everything that won't contribute immediately to our profitability... The CAMERA APPROACHES a man in his sixties, STEVENS, dron on. WE DON'T SLOW, continue along the row of exec faces. STEVENS (cont'd) Selecting thirty-seven as promising strategic growth programs and setting aside the rest for future consideration. Until we finally ARRIVE at the placard in front of a bore Eugene McClary Executive Vice-President - Transportation Systems Doodling an elaborate geometric design on a hotel note pa As Stevens finishes, several analysts raise their hands.

dialogues.speaker: HASPEL
dialogues.text: Ned Haspel, JP Morgan. Mr. McClary, you were talking earlier about fiscal 2011, you've done a good job of convincing us that with the credit markets frozen, your sales revenue in 2010 will slow --

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Great, then my job here is done. That gets a laugh from the analysts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 4 "The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 5.

dialogues.speaker: HASPEL
dialogues.text: Can you talk about 2011 and what sort of a percentage increase you anticipate?

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: People love to talk about percentages Ned, our people do, you people do. But when we do sales forecasts in a mature manufacturing sector like transportation, we should be focusing on how to maintain growth in absolute dollars.

dialogues.speaker: HASPEL
dialogues.text: Are you suggesting you aren't expecting any growth in your division next year? Stevens looks down the dais at Gene, worried.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: I'm suggesting that we face increased foreign competition and a difficult market for large capital expenditures like shipbuilding, so 2011 will probably end even or a little up from 2010. I call that an excellent result in this credit climate but you're probably going to call it disappointing. Stevens looks quickly for another hand.

dialogues.speaker: STEVENS
dialogues.text: Another question?

dialogues.speaker: HASPEL
dialogues.text: So no growth in 2011? Gene avoids Stevens concerned look, stares down Haspel fo long moment, then goes back to the company script.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: I'm confident that while shipbuilding will remain challenged, the rest of the Transportation Systems Group will continue to contribute significant growth to GTX in coming quarters. Haspel's still unsatisfied but Gene points to another han GENE (cont'd) Yes, in the back. Off Gene's frozen smile as an analyst begins a question w

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: "The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 6.

dialogues.speaker: GTX CORPORATE HEADQUARTERS
dialogues.text: A glass and metal cathedral of commerce. Acres of unfette capitalism surrounded by manicured lawns and parking lots Bobby pulls his Porsche into his spot. Hits his alarm, VOOP! The lot is a lesson in corporate automotive hierarchy; Volvos, Hondas and Excursions give to BMWs, Range Rovers and Jaguars nearer the door.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE GTX BUILDING
dialogues.text: Bobby crosses the lobby, four stories of atrium rises abo mature elms rustle in the artificial breeze, granite floo polished ice rink slick. The huge corporate logo announce GTX Global Transportation Systems We Keep The World Moving!

dialogues.speaker: SHIP SYSTEMS OFFICES
dialogues.text: DING! He steps off the elevator, pushes through glass doo and past the large reception desk, the omnipresent "GTX" looming behind it. Crosses to a set of glass doors, "Ship Systems - Marketing and Sales" etched into them and down long hallway toward -~

dialogues.speaker: TRANSPORTATION SYSTEMS SALES DEPARTMENT
dialogues.text: Secretarial desks, rows of cubicles for the worker bees, heads for a windowed office and his secretary, CAROL.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Any messages? He doesn't wait, grabs them off her desk. She's a little distant. He doesn't notice, shuffles through them.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Wilcox wants to see you, she's in the fifth floor conference room.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Shot an eighty-six this morning. He doesn't. wait for an answer, heads off down the row of desks. She calls after him, he doesn't stop. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10 "The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 7.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: She said it was important.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Sally Wilcox thinks everything's important. An eighty-six!

dialogues.speaker: GLASS WALLED CONFERENCE ROOM 9
dialogues.text: Eight young execs in mid-meeting, LAKE, JANE. Bobby heads for a chair, peeling off his suit-jacket.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Anybody want to guess what I shot at the club this morning? They're all staring at him, it's uncomfortable. BOBBY (cont'd) 44 on the front, 42 on the back. (he stops/realizes) What's up, somebody die? Dead silence. Bobby takes a beat, looks through the glass wall out to the people staring in from the hallway. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY 10
dialogues.text: Bobby FLINGS open the door, passes frightened faces stari up at him. A secretary, BARBARA, stands by an office door

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Conal? CONAL DOHERTY, sixties, packing a couple of boxes. A stun woman in her forties sits on Conal's sofa, DIANE LINDSTRO

dialogues.speaker: CONAL
dialogues.text: They closed Mobile and Newport News, merged Ship Systems into Rail Products.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: How many?

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Conal, your wife's on one.

dialogues.speaker: CONAL
dialogues.text: Hello, honey. I've got some bad news -- Bobby looks to Diane, she brushes away a few stray tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 8.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Three thousand at the shipyards, rumor is another couple hundred here.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 11 INT. GTX OFFICES, HUMAN RESOURCES - DAY a1 Bobby heads for a corner office. A discreet sign announce "Sally Wilcox Vice-President Human Resources", SHOVES int

dialogues.speaker: WILCOX'S OFFICE 12
dialogues.text: Floor to ceiling glass with a lovely view of the rolling Massachusetts hills and Boston beyond. Some art, a few plants, and SALLY WILCOX, tailored, attractive.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: What the hell is going on?

dialogues.speaker: WILCOX
dialogues.text: Bobby, you know Dick Landry from Legal? A balding, average man sits at the small conference table

dialogues.speaker: LANDRY
dialogues.text: The company's consolidating divisions. Difficult decisions had to be made in areas where redundancies surfaced. Bobby stares at them, can't believe where this is going. LANDRY (cont'd) We've structured a generous severance package for you. Your twelve years with us entitles you to twelve weeks full pay and benefits.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: You're firing me? He presents it as ludicrous on it's face, she doesn't lau

dialogues.speaker: WILCOX
dialogues.text: Come on Bobby, sit down.

dialogues.speaker: LANDRY
dialogues.text: We're also offering you outplacement services to help you secure your next employment. The room's spinning, Bobby tries to get his bearings. (CONTTNIED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 12 13 14 15 “The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 9.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Does Gene know about this?

dialogues.speaker: WILCOX
dialogues.text: Bobby please, sit. But instead of sitting, he heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Hey Sally, you know what? Fuck off. And he's gone. A long silence. She looks at her shoes.

dialogues.speaker: LANDRY
dialogues.text: Friend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby makes his way to the big office at the end of the h Pushes through etched doors that announce: * Eugene McClary Executive Vice President - Transportation Systems

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: He in there? * Bobby doesn't wait for an answer, strides into:

dialogues.speaker: GENE'S OFFICE 14
dialogues.text: Large, beautifully furnished. Conference table, sofa, oversized desk, carefully framed 19th century sectional blueprints of the first steam powered cargo ships and mod

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of military and civilian ships. Empty. *

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: He's in Chicago today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE FOLLOW a chauffeured town car as it pulls up next to a waiting Gulfstream, the GTX logo on it's fuselage. Gene a Stevens climb out of the car. Stevens is pissed.

dialogues.speaker: STEVENS
dialogues.text: Honesty's the best policy? Gene doesn't answer, starts for the plane's stairs. ({CONTTNURD )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 10. 15 CONTINUED: is STEVENS (cont'd) Christ, could you try, just try, to be a little less candid for once?

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: So we're lying to financial analysts now? That the new profitability plan? Follow them up the steps and into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blonde woods and beige leather seats. Fresh flowers and newspapers arrayed on the serving buffet. A waiting GTX stewardess takes their coats.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: What do you want? More inflated guidance so we can under perform every quarter again next year? Gene takes the best seat in the middle of the cabin.

dialogues.speaker: STEVENS
dialogues.text: 20112 I'm worried about the damn share price tomorrow. But Gene isn't listening, stares out the window sullenly the engine's power up. STEVENS (cont'd) Salinger's gonna blow a fucking gasket. cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY'S OFFICE 17
dialogues.text: Bobby steps back into his office. Three brand new, empty packing boxes are already sitting on his desk.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Oh shit... An anxious man in the door eyeing the boxes, PHIL WOODWAR

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: What'd you get?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Twelve weeks and outplacement.

dialogues.speaker: 17A
dialogues.text: 18 "The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 11.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: They say who else is on the block?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Thanks for the sympathy, Phil.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I'm not an MBA like you. I get canned, I'm working at Kinkos. (starts for the door) Call you later, okay? And he's gone. Bobby looks around the office. The family photos, the nice view, the waxed plants. Picks up his bra desk plate "Robert Walker, Jr.". Throws it into a box. *

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Did they say anything about me?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: About my still having a job? It never even occurred to him, he stares at her dumbly.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I didn't ask. She turns slowly, goes. *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby steps off the elevators, carrying his box, the blaz guards watch from the security desk. He stops for a momen the vast lobby. Other fired workers pass. He takes one la look around, in shock. Starts out -- *

dialogues.speaker: THE GTX PARKING LOT
dialogues.text: Bobby crosses the lot, the GTX building rising up behind

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: accusingly, still carrying his boxes. Many cars are alrea gone. Ruptured lives captured in a still life of empty parking spots. Others carry similar boxes, plants, knickknacks. Men, women. Trunks open, car doors. Bobby nods as he passes, the faces haunted, frightened. A woman in the spot next to him loads her few things, tea streaming down her face, it's the woman from Conal's offi Diane. They stare at each other for a moment. He doesn't

dialogues.speaker: 18A
dialogues.text: 19 20 221 "The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 12.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: know what to say, so he doesn't say anything. Climbs in, turns the engine OVER, pulls out.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL'S GTX OFFICE
dialogues.text: From somewhere above, we look down at the emptying parkin lot, Bobby's Porsche backing out and pulling away. A man' face enters frame, CLOSE, turning away from the window. It's Phil, watching his fired friends driving away.

dialogues.speaker: WELLESLEY STREET
dialogues.text: Beautiful trees, lovely brick homes. Bobby turns the Pors into his drive. The garage door RISES to reveal: empty concrete, it's perimeter packed with bikes, skis, bats, b and all manner of sporting goods. cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY'S HOUSE 20
dialogues.text: The living room nobody uses, the large kitchen and family room, wide screen plasma TV and tangle of Nintendo cords. Bobby sets his box on the kitchen butcher block. The afternoon silence broken only by the HUM of the refrigera and someone MOWING a lawn several blocks away. Now what? cut TO: GTX BUILDING - EXECUTIVE FLOOR ELEVATORS al The doors OPEN, Gene steps off. Pushes into his suite.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Miss me?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: I've been trying to reach you. He heads for his office, pulls out a cell phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Battery's dead. (throws it to her) Charge it, will ya?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Phil's in there. {CONTTNUED ¥

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 21 22 “The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 12A.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Karen follows Gene into:

dialogues.speaker: GENE'S OFFICE 22
dialogues.text: Phil waits on the sofa, overflowing ashtray beside him.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Make yourself at home, Phil.

dialogues.speaker: 22A
dialogues.text: 23 “The Company Men" Shooting Draft Pinks 4/13/09 13.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I won't go back to a factory floor. I've got one kid in college, another one going in the fall.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: What the hell are you talking about? Phil looks at Karen.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: You're shitting me, he doesn't know?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Sally Wilcox let some more people go.

dialogues.speaker: PEIL
dialogues.text: Some? She fired goddam everybody! Gene's staring at Phil. What?

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: She fired you?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: No, but I've been hiding in here all day.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: They closed Mobile and Newport News. Laid off most of the Ship Systems Sales Group. Conal, Bobby, Ted, Diane -- Gene doesn't need to hear more, he's already heading out.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I won't let the bastards just kick me out after thirty years. I'll take an AK-47 to this fucking place first!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gene bursts from the elevator, pushes into --

dialogues.speaker: OFFICE OF THE CEO 23
dialogues.text: Gene heads for the elegant reception area, subdued lighti antiques, framed covers of FORBES, FORTUNE. Two secretari flank the inner doors, one tries to intercept, JILL.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: He's in a meeting, Mr. McClary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "The Company Men" Shooting Draft Goldenrod 5/15/09 14.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: But she isn't fast enough.

dialogues.speaker: SALINGER'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: More antiques, art. Hotel lobbies are smaller. Five execs around a conference table, in it's center sits an architectural model of an impressive skyscraper.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: ++.SEC wants more detail on the stock options the compensation committee just --

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: What were you going to do? Let me read about it in tomorrow's Journal? Gene's yelling at the man seated at the head of the table Fifties, greying and charismatic, JAMES SALINGER.

dialogues.speaker: SALINGER
dialogues.text: We're in the middle of something here --

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: You closed two of my ship yards?

dialogues.speaker: SALINGER
dialogues.text: Consolidating divisions has been under discussion for months.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Yeah, and I told you it was a shitty idea. The other men at the table stare at their shoes, trying t stay out of the crossfire, very uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: SALINGER
dialogues.text: Your opinion was taken into --

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: It's my goddam division!

dialogues.speaker: SALINGER
dialogues.text: And it's my goddam company! Utter silence. Then Salinger turns to the others, evenly: | SALINGER (cont'd) Excuse us gentlemen, would you please? The execs beat a hasty retreat as the two men stare at ea other. As soon as they're gone, irritated:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 24 “The Company Men" Shooting Draft Goldenrod 5/15/09 15.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: SALINGER (cont'd) Don't embarrass me like that.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: I'm gone for a day and you gut one of my divisions?

dialogues.speaker: SALINGER
dialogues.text: Stock's stalled, revenues are flat.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: The entire economy is flat. We're in the middie of a damn recession. Salinger moves behind his desk, searching for something.

dialogues.speaker: SALINGER
dialogues.text: I only closed two of the shipyards, I should have closed all three. Our stock's in the fucking toilet.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Everybody's stock's in the toilet.

dialogues.speaker: SALINGER
dialogues.text: The stockholders need to see their share value maximized.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then sel] the damn Degas -- Over the desk. Shit, it is a Degas. Salinger doesn't engage, searches around on his desk until he finds a note

dialogues.speaker: SALINGER
dialogues.text: Heard you put on quite a show in Chicago. You told a roomful of analysts you're not going to generate any growth next year?

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Three thousand jobs?

dialogues.speaker: SALINGER
dialogues.text: Ship System's labor costs are the highest in the industry, your health care and pension obligations are exploding.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: We're in a capital intensive industry -- in case you forgot -- and credit markets are frozen. We're looking for ways to cut costs --

dialogues.speaker: CCONTTNORD \
dialogues.text: “The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Salinger’ patience is running thin. They've had this argument before, many times.

dialogues.speaker: SALINGER
dialogues.text: You're getting killed by the Japanese and the Koreans. Hell, even the fucking Vietnamese are handing you your lunch.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: We'll figure it out, I just need --

dialogues.speaker: SALINGER
dialogues.text: Christ Gene, we're not some shitty little shipyard anymore! I can't keep pouring money into your --

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: We innovate, we re-tool --

dialogues.speaker: SALINGER
dialogues.text: American heavy manufacturing is dead. Steel, autos, and your precious ship yards. Our future is in health care, infrastructure, power generation.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: I have to be included in any decision that involves one of my divisions. 16. 24 (CONTTNUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 17.

dialogues.speaker: SALINGER
dialogues.text: You wouldn't have agreed to the cuts. You would have gone behind my back to the Board again! Right...? Gene doesn't answer. Salinger's right, he would have. The stand there for a moment, staring at each other. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: They were good people, Jim.

dialogues.speaker: SALINGER
dialogues.text: They're.not our responsibility. We work for the stockholders now.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 24A EXT. BOBBY'S HOUSE - LATE AFTERNOON ‘ 24a A car pulls into the driveway, pulls into the garage next Bobby's Porsche. A woman climbs out, MAGGIE WALKER, prett thirties. Reaches into the back for groceries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's enter's from the garage, arms loaded with groceries a new garden hose.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Drew...? Help... Her twelve-year-old son, DREW, is doing homework at the kitchen table, comes over to help her. MAGGIE (cont'd) +..thanks... As Maggie and Drew drop the groceries on the kitchen isla Maggie sees Bobby outside on the patio. To Drew: MAGGIE (cont'd) Your Dad's home? She makes her way to the patio door, steps --

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE
dialogues.text: Bobby is cooking chicken at the big stainless-steel barbe sleeves rolled up, tie still tied. Their ten-year-old daughter, CARSON, is playing with the dog in the yard bel {CONT TNIRD ¥  "The Company Men" Shooting Draft Goldenrod 5/15/09 18.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: MAGGIE (cont’d) What're you doing home?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Cooking dinner. She stares at him for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: We're going over to Jack's.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: That's tonight?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Diedre's birthday.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: It's supposed to rain. She turns angrily, heads back into --

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You don't want to come, fine, don't come.

dialogues.speaker: THE KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Starts unloading the groceries angrily. Bobby follows her realizes Drew's staring at them.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Drew, finish that upstairs, okay? Drew gathers up his homework, Maggie calls after him.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Put on a clean pair of jeans, we're going over to Uncle Jack's for a barbecue. (when Drew's gone) Christ, you don't have to like him, but you could pretend for my sake.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Maggie --

dialogues.speaker: . MAGGIE
dialogues.text: He doesn't like you either but at least he cares enough about me not to treat you like shit.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: They fired me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 25 “The Company Men" Shooting Draft Goldenrod 5/15/09 19.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She stops. Stares at him, what? BOBBY (cont'd) Today. Sally Wilcox.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: {she's in shock) Why?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Something about redundancies.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Gene said you were safe...

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Yeah well, Gene said a lot of things but he was nowhere to be found today. {she's too stunned to speak) They gave me a severance package. Three months pay, benefits. She flares, his protector.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Well, fuck them. You've busted your ass for that company. (he smiles) No. Really, I mean it. Fuck them. And fuck Gene McClary and all his promises. He keeps smiling, you've got to, her spousal ferocity.

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: Something's burning... Carson is watching them from the open patio door. How lon she been there? But she's right, the grill is smoking.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Shit... Be runs back outside, Maggie follows, watches him pull charred, flaming chicken halves off the grill. They stand there for a beat, then Maggie shoos Carson away.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Go get ready for the party, honey.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I don't want to tell anybody. Not till I get another job. She looks off, concerned. Doesn't answer. (CONTTNITED 1)

dialogues.speaker: 25A
dialogues.text: 26 27 "The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 20.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BOBBY (cont'd) Okay? She nods. Bobby gives her that winning salesman's smile. BOBBY (cont'd) We're going to be fine. cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil pulls his late model sedan into the driveway of his brick home. Climbs out, looks up at the house, apprehensi Pulls his briefcase from the car. Starts in. * CcuT TO: *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil steps through his front door, tosses keys into a dis The house is comfortable but a little tired, middle-class family photos everywhere. Makes his way into -- *

dialogues.speaker: THE DINING ROOM 27
dialogues.text: Finds his daughter SARAH, seventeen, pouring over a textb laptop. She barely glances up, he leans in, kisses her he

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Where's your mother? (she doesn't respond) ...Sarah? He hadn't noticed the thin-white strands of her I-Pod sna out from under her hair. Taps her on the shoulder. PHIL (cont'd) Your mom?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Upstairs. She had a headache. Father and daughter share a knowing look. He starts out. SARAH (cont'd) Dad? They told us where we're going for * senior trip. Italy.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Italy, wow. That's great. But he's elsewhere, staring up at the ceiling. (CONTTNURFD )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 27 28 “The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 21.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I can go, right?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Of course, sweetheart. He smiles, she smiles back -- Daddy's girl. Returns to he studies. He steals one final glance to the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wool wall-to-wall carpeting, dark colonial reproductions, more family photos. Phil finds her passed out on top of t comforter, fully clothed, shoes kicked off. An empty wine glass on the end-table. He exhales, starts for the closet

dialogues.speaker: LORNA
dialogues.text: +..Phil? He looks back to find her watching him groggily from the LORNA (cont'd) Ann Doherty called, they fired Conal? He nods, pulls off his coat, tie, hangs them in the close She sits on the edge of the bed, trying to get her bearin LORNA (cont'd) I tried your office, are we okay? (he nods again) You're sure? He hates it when she's like this. Forces a reassuring smi

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Yeah, Gene spoke to Wilcox. (then) I should get ready. (she stares blankly) Salinger's dinner?

dialogues.speaker: LORNA
dialogues.text: Oh god, I completely forgot.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: You don't have to come if you're not feeling up to it. He's hoping she won't but she stands, heads for the bath.

dialogues.speaker: LORNA
dialogues.text: dust give me a minute to put my face on.

dialogues.speaker: 28A
dialogues.text: 29 30 "The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 22.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Disappears inside, then the sound of water running in a s Phil exhales again, stares at the empty wineglass.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT, GENE'S HOUSE - LATE AFTERNOON 28a Gene's Aston Martin. roars along the single lane road lea to his long driveway and his seaside home. The garage doo rises slowly, he pulls the car into it's spot in the immaculate space. Climbs out, starts for the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gene enters, drops his briefcase on the table in the larg entrance hall. The house is Architectural Digest perfect, flowers, art. Makes his way to the drink cart in --

dialogues.speaker: THE LIVING ROOM 30
dialogues.text: Cut crystal tumblers, antiques and art. Finds the scotch, takes a few ice cubes from the waiting ice bucket.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA, (OS)
dialogues.text: Gene...? CYNTHIA McCLARY appears, fifties, hair already done, make robe, elegant. She's a little irritated. CYNTHIA (cont'd) Where've you been, the car's picking us up in half-an-hour? She waits, but he doesn't answer. She doesn't pursue it. CYNTHIA (cont'd) Wait till you see the dress I found at Louis'. Salvatore Ferragamo. Fabulous. (points as she goes) . Stephanie finally brought a table by for the window. I like it. Over by the window, a spindly antique table with an orchi perched on top. He wanders to it, the ribbon tied price t discreetly attached to the single drawer. Turns it over: "18th Century Windsor Side Table $18,500.00" He looks up, catches his distorted reflection in the anti panes of the window, not sure he likes what he sees, as w

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 31 32 "The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 23.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's still light out. Bobby pulls the Volvo to the curb i front of a modest home in a working-class neighborhood. Stares at the pickup trucks and minivans in the drive, th boat in the yard. He looks at his wife, do they have to go? Yes. She grabs gift, climbs out with the kids. Bobby follows reluctantly

dialogues.speaker: JACK'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: A big plasma TV dominates the living room, blaring a Sox game. Several men gathered around, watching. The kitchen table groans under piles of chips, beer and pizzas still their delivery boxes.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: We won't stay long. Promise? She follows the kids out into the back yard. Bob drifts to the kitchen, staring out the open sliding door the rear deck.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: How go the suit wars, Bobby? JACK DOLAN, Maggie's brother, high school quarterback handsome, with the broad, calloused hands and weathered f of a man who works for a living. He's cutting the celloph off supermarket steaks and plates of brats -- plopping th down on a platter in the tiny kitchen. Bobby hadn't seen JACK (cont'd) Move any more high-paying American jobs offshore to Asian shitholes this week?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Been concentrating on union busting lately, Jack. Jack grins, this is an old routine with them. Stabs the steaks with a carving fork to tenderize, then liberally s the meat, then douses them with Worchester sauce.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Surprised you could make it, no early flight or golf game? Those are the usual excuses, aren't they?

dialogues.speaker: DIEDRE
dialogues.text: Hey, Bobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ee *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 32 33 "The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 24.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Jack's attractive wife, DIEDRE, steps in from outside.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: The birthday girl. You can't be thirty- five. You don't look a day over twenty.

dialogues.speaker: DIEDRE
dialogues.text: See Jack, that's how it's done.. You're a liar Bobby, but I love you for it. (kisses Jack/shoves him out) Back to your post barbecue boy. Jack heads out with the meat. Diedre turns to Bobby. DIEDRE (cont'd) Get something to drink, Margaritas in the blender, beer's in the cooler out back. He watches her walk away, short skirt, long legs -- he's right, she does looks great. A Diedre friend in the livin room catches him looking, smirks at him, turns back to th woman she was talking with. Bobby makes his way out onto --

dialogues.speaker: THE DECK
dialogues.text: Beers on ice in a gigantic cooler, working men and women laughing, telling jokes. The picnic table groans under it load of paper plates and potluck. Below, Jack hands off the meat to a man at the big Weber the yard (we'll come to know later as DAVEY) wades into a pick-up football game with a pack of boys, including his three (14, 12 and 10) and their cousin, Drew. Jack intercepts the ball from Drew, pretends to run, let' the boys tackle him in the yard, pile on. All the boys ar laughing, nobody harder than Jack. Off Bobby, miserable.

dialogues.speaker: HARVARD CLUB BALLROOM
dialogues.text: Men and women in cocktail attire mill around the overtaxe bars. Banquet tables, a dais up front under a banner proclaiming "Boston Sons of Liberty Man of the Year". Gene makes his way through the well-heeled crowd, Cynthia his arm in her Ferragamo. Phil and Lorna trail behind the Lorna already working a glass of wine. They pass faces we recognize; Wilcox, Landry, Archer. Glad-handing, laughter

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 33 "The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 25.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: cocktails. Gene glances to Wilcox surreptitiously, Cynthi notices. Phil hangs back to say something to Lake and Jan forces a smile.

dialogues.speaker: PRIL
dialogues.text: Hey, kids. The young execs are shocked to see him, share looks. PHIL (cont'd) You look surprised to see me Ken, you planning on eating my entree?

dialogues.speaker: LAKE
dialogues.text: Phil..., great to see you. We thought --

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Never bet against the old fucker, Kenny. I still got a few teeth left in my head. Catches back up to Gene as a confident man in his fifties passes Phil and the young execs, saunters up to Gene offe his hand, DYSERT.

dialogues.speaker: DYSERT
dialogues.text: Saw your name on tonight's program, Gene. I trust brevity is in order.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Absolutely Chuck, how's life at Betcher? A Brooks Brothers suited handler leans in to Cynthia, whispers something we can't hear as Dysert continues:

dialogues.speaker: DYSERT
dialogues.text: EPA's killing us.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: The bastards. What's the big deal about dumping toxic waste into the Hudson, huh?

dialogues.speaker: DYSERT
dialogues.text: Exactly what I said at my deposition. Cynthia takes Gene's arm, leads him away from the group.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: Gene, they need us up front.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Say hello to Ellen for me, would you? Dysert and Phil watch them disappear into the crowd, then (CONTTNURD )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 33 34 “The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 26.

dialogues.speaker: DYSERT
dialogues.text: Hell of a bloodbath out your way today. You watching your back? Phil's taken aback, but only for a moment. Covers.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Always.

dialogues.speaker: DYSERT
dialogues.text: Good, glad to hear it... (seeing someone) Hey Jeff! ...Take care, Phil. Heads off to do more networking. Phil watches him go, dro the facade. Sneaks a look back to Lorna who's been listen to this exchange anxiously. Off Phil we --

dialogues.speaker: THE BALLROOM
dialogues.text: Dinner has come and gone, half-eaten desserts litter tabl the houselights have been dimmed. A man at the podium:

dialogues.speaker: SPEAKER
dialogues.text: I promised Charlie Welsh I'd get him out of here in time to catch the end of the Sox game, so let's get to it. (some laughter) Who better to introduce tonight's Man of the Year Award winner than the man who's known him longer than anyone else. Gene and Cynthia are on the dais next to Salinger and wif SPEAKER (cont'd) Gene McClary is Executive Vice-President at GTX Global Transportation Systems, as well as serving on its Board of Directors. He's also, I'm told, one of GTX's first employees. Gene McClary. Warm applause greets Gene on his journey to the podium.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Actually, if memory serves correct, I was GTX's only employee at the time. (scattered laughter) We weren't GTX then. We were a couple of kids fresh out of business school, with more energy than sense, and a crazy idea. A crazy idea that my friend Jim Salinger had the talent, determination and (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 34 35 36 "The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 27.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: GENE (cont'd) foresight to turn into one of the largest manufacturing, health care and financial services companies in the world. Salinger tries to look humble. It's a stretch. GENE (cont'd) No one wanted Gloucester Shipbuilders, years of multi-million dollar losses, the highest labor costs in the industry. But from those humble beginnings, Jim grew Gloucester into GTX, with over sixty thousand employees and eleven billion dollars in gross annual revenues. That gets applause from this crowd. GENE (cont'd) I could go on and on, but we all want Charlie to catch that game. So, it is my great privilege to introduce my oldest friend, my college roommate, the best man at my wedding, the worst tennis player I know, my boss, Jim Salinger. Salinger makes his way to the podium, shakes Gene's hand. Gene steps back into the shadows as Salinger basks in the APPLAUSE. Off Gene, the outline of his features barely visible in the half light, distant, troubled. cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: DARKENED BEDROOM ' 35
dialogues.text: Heavy with sleep and rumpled sheets. Shards of morning li are just beginning to fight their way through drawn drape Maggie stirs, sits up slowly. No Bobby in bed beside her.

dialogues.speaker: BATHROOM
dialogues.text: Finds him at the mirror, pulling on a crisp white shirt, Barney's suit, silk tie. Bloomberg playing on the small T

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: It's five-thirty.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Stock was up yesterday. Hands her his Journal off the sink, points to a headline. “Transportation Issues Buoyed By GTX Downsizing News."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 36 37 38 39 "The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 28.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BOBBY (cont'd) Nice to know I could be of use, huh? (then) How do I look? She adjusts his tie, kisses him.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Like a million bucks.

dialogues.speaker: ELEVATOR LOBBY
dialogues.text: Bobby exits the elevators, enters the lobby of --

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN, KASEY
dialogues.text: He waits as the receptionist answers the busy phone.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Executive offices. (and another line) Executive offices. She's not even looking up. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Robert Walker, from GTX.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Down on your left. Bobby looks in the direction of her indistinct arm motion Moves through the door into the --

dialogues.speaker: MK
dialogues.text: A large open room, filled with a maze of low cubicles. An everywhere men and women are making calls. Some in suit a tie, some in jeans. Bobby stares. Christ, it's telemarketing meets a language lab. The walls display framed motivational catchphrases: "Enthusiasm", "Courage", "Confidence"

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Nice suit. DANNY MILLS, forties, Black, jeans. Bemused by Bobby's fu court clothing press. Bobby doesn't catch the sarcasm.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Thanks. (CONTTNURD )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 39 40 "The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 29.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Orientation's that way. Do the Tiger for me, will ya?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: What ? Danny points to the orientation room.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Across the hall.

dialogues.speaker: MK
dialogues.text: A circle of chairs, men and women in their business best. Standing in the center, JOANNA, blonde, imposing, pants s

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: First, let me tell you what outplacement is not. We're not an employment agency. We're here to help you help yourself. He looks around, sees Conal Doherty, Diane Lindstrom, a f others he recognizes. Joanna passes around thick handouts JOANNA (cont'd) You need to make a networking list of all your friends, business and personal. Suppliers, competitors, people you sat next to at a convention, neighbors, dentists. Anybody and everybody. Hands a packet to Bobby. Glossy charts, blank forms. JOANNA (cont'd) You need a new resume. You're going to send out hundreds, so make it good. She turns to the easel, grabs a magic marker, writes. Bob tries to hide his growing unease. What's he doing here? JOANNA (cont'd) Endings. We're not used to them. Fear, chaos, anxiety, loss. How many of you are feeling these things? Only a few raise their hands. Bobby sneaks a look to Cona and Diane, Jesus... Joanna writes: JOANNA (cont'd) Endings, fear, change, and finally... (CONTTNITED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 40 41 "The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 30.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Draws a line: “endings” leads to "fear" leads to “change" leads to "SUCCESS". She taps her marker on -- JOANNA (cont'd) Success. Stand up everybody, there's no time for sitting around feeling sorry for ourselves. Up, UP! We call this "The Tiger". We do it when we need to get our energy up. Some stand quickly, others lag -- Bobby chief among the laggards. She chants a mantra. JOANNA (cont'd) I... will... win. Why? I'11 show you why! Because I have -- Faith! Courage! Enthusiasm! Bobby stares, motivational aerobics? Only about half the room is standing. JOANNA (cont'd) Come on, everybody. Conal stands reluctantly, Diane.

dialogues.speaker: THE GROUP
dialogues.text: I... will... win... Bobby still sits, staring at his fellow fired. Can't beli it. Yesterday he's canned, today he's trapped in a room w a bunch of unemployed executive Moonies.

dialogues.speaker: GENE'S GTX OUTER OFFICE
dialogues.text: Gene arrives, late, pulling off his coat. Karen meets him

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Bobby Walker call back?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Yeah, last night.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: He leave a message?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Not one I'd care to repeat.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: See if he can come by for lunch today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 41 42 43 "The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 31. CONTINUED: 4l

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Stock's up six. Not bad. (smiles ruefully) My 401K is all GTX. This continues I may get to retire before I'm eighty. Hands him a stack of thick black binders as he heads into

dialogues.speaker: THE CONFERENCE ROOM 42
dialogues.text: To find his senior sales execs. Phil, Lake, Jane, others. There's laughter. The morale's not bad, more like relief.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: With Ship Systems and Rail Products merged we're reassigning sales regions. Hands out binders. A few chairs around the table are vaca as if those who used to occupy them may have been contagi GENE (cont'd) Phil, where are we on Royal Caribbean?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: They're nervous, don't like seeing us on Bloomberg every fifteen minutes.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Well calm ‘em down, we need that boat. The unhappy execs thumb through the binders, incredulous.

dialogues.speaker: LAKE
dialogues.text: How're we supposed to cover the same number of accounts with half the staff?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I'm already gone two weeks out of four, what am I supposed to tell my kids?

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Tell ‘em you're lucky you still have a job. Inactive accounts. I want to know what we're going to do to get the business back. Client by client. A groan goes up as they settle in for a long morning and

dialogues.speaker: MK
dialogues.text: The group comes out of Orientation and into the bullpen, Conal, Diane and Bobby bringing up the rear. Like musical

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 43 "The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 32.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: chairs when the tune stops, spots are quickly taken. The timers glare at the newbies as they pass. Bobby spies a seemingly open carrel, goes to sit. The man next to the empty spot waves him off coldly.

dialogues.speaker: BALDING MAN
dialogues.text: It's taken, Bobby looks around, everything appears full. Perfect.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Hey. Danny Mills, the man Bobby met earlier, motions him over. Pulls a jacket and a few things out of the carrel next to him, stuffs them under his own carrel.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Friendly bunch.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: You're the enemy. One more warm body they have to claw their way over to get back to the corporate feed trough.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: You don't seem threatened.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I'm a very secure individual. Besides, you don't look like an engineer. MBA? (Bobby nods) If you knew your way around a guided missile system I'd have to shove an ice pick into the base of your skull. Bobby looks at his new "office", two feet by three feet, well-used phone, yellow pad covered with the last occupan doodles, a couple of used pencils. DANNY (cont'd) Your previous employer spared no expense. Fax is over there, coffee, Xerox. (smiles) How was orientation?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I thought somebody was gonna shave my head and make me beat a drum. Danny laughs. Bobby points to the series of outer offices small, but with windows and a door you can close for priv

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: "The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 33.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOBBY (cont'd) How early do you have to get here to grab one of the offices?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Your company has to pay extra for one. Exec VPs and above mostly. That corner one has an Eastman-Kodak CFO in it. * (and) How long did they give you?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Three months full pay, four months of outplacement. Danny's taken aback, tries not to show it. But Danny the phone, dials. Danny studies Bobby. The expensive suit BOBBY (cont'd) You?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Nine months of both, I've been here four.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I won't need more than a few days. No offense.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: None taken. is a little. Bobby sets down his things, picks up *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the silk tie. Turns away with the resigned sadness of a weary veteran watching green recruits arrive at the front Cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: THE OYSTER HOUSE
dialogues.text: A crowded wharf-side seafood joint. Gene arrives, pushing * through the throng to find Bobby nursing a drink at a boo among the hurly-burly of the lunchtime business set.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Sorry I'm late, how you holding up?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Maggie's alright?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Sure, she's fine. We're both fine. (CONTTNUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 34.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Bobby's holding back, angry. The waitress arrives.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Glenlivet, rocks. (she goes) It wasn't my call, Bobby. We believe him, Bobby doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Who gets my accounts?

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Salinger's under pressure to boost the stock price before someone comes in and forces him to break up the company. A lot more jobs would be lost in a merger than in this downsizing.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: You trying to appeal to my sense of the greater corporate good?

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: I've been calling in some markers -- Gene offers Bobby a folded list of names, phone numbers. GENE (cont'd) Tom Borden at Lockheed, Pat Leahy at Raytheon, you'll recognize most of them. Bobby doesn't take it. It's awkward. Finally Gene reaches for the menu stuck in behind the napkin dispenser. GENE (cont'd) Come on, let's get something to eat.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: (takes a beat) No thanks. I've lost my appetite. Bobby stands, hasn't taken Gene's list of names.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Bobby. Take the names. Bobby reaches across, takes the list as he goes.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Don't waste your time reassigning my accounts. I'm going to be stealing them (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 44 45 46 "The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 35.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BOBBY (cont'd) back from you as soon as I get a job working for your competition.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY'S GARAGE
dialogues.text: Bobby pulls the Porsche into the drive, the garage door sliding up- Drew shoots baskets in the driveway, has to b out of the way as his Dad's Porsche glides by. Bobby gets out wearily, sees Drew standing there in the driveway, watching him, wills back his confidence for his son's sake --

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Hey...

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Hey... Bobby goes into the house. Drew watches him go, then turn back to his solitary game --

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY'S HOUSE 46
dialogues.text: Carson and a noisy girlfriend run around the den. Bobby finds Maggie at the kitchen table, papers spread around h

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: How'd it go?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Great.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: “Great..."?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: It was fine, lots of leads. I had lunch with Gene, he gave me some names.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: That was big of hin.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: He didn't have to do anything. Bobby pulls a kid's juice box out of the fridge, jams the little straw into it's top, eyes the mess on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 36.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BOBBY (cont'd) What's all that? *

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Our mortgage resets next month. With * paying off the orthodontist and last * summer's Disneyworld trip, we don't have * much of a cushion left.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: We don't need a cushion.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: The Porsche payments, the credit cards, your Patriots tickets.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I'm splitting the Pats tickets with Darryl this year.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Just eating out and doing the damn dry * cleaning is costing us six hundred bucks a month. I was thinking I could go back to work, not full-time just a few shifts. *

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: No. 3M is looking for a new General Sales Manager. I called Brian Collins, we're having breakfast next week.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: We need to at least cut back. Cancel skiing at Christmas, stop paying the club dues for a while... He tosses his empty juice box into the trash, irritated.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: We get into real trouble, I can always bag groceries or pump gas. She stares at him, not amused. The phone begins to RING.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: No big purchases, eat at home more. (answers the phone) Hello... Hey, Kevin. Bobby grimaces, signals - "I'm not here." MAGGIE (cont'd) No. He's right here... (CONTTNITED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 46 47 "The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 37.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Bobby smirks, she covers the mouthpiece with her hand. MAGGIE (cont'd) He read about the layoffs in the paper, you going to tell him?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Hell no. I don't need a lecture on my paternal responsibilities right now. (takes the phone) Hi, Dad...no, that was in manufacturing. Are you kidding? They're begging me to take the CEO job. Had to turn ‘em down -- She stands, watching unhappily as he spins his bullshit -

dialogues.speaker: GENE'S GTX OFFICE
dialogues.text: Gene's pouring over thick cost reports, jacket off, glass Is interrupted by a KNOCK on his open door.

dialogues.speaker: SALINGER
dialogues.text: I come bearing gifts. He carries a bottle of Scotch, two glasses. Jacket off, t loose. Plops down in the chair in front of Gene's desk. SALINGER (cont'd) (CONT'D) Glenury Royal. 50 year old single malt. Gene eyes Salinger warily as Salinger opens the bottle, p two generous drinks.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Nice.

dialogues.speaker: SALINGER
dialogues.text: Better be. Strick sent it over, bastard lost me a bundle on some bullshit hedge fund play on distressed financials. (hands Gene a glass) You and Cynthia going to join us in Sun Valley for New Years again this year? Kay's been asking.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Not sure we can. Liam's talking about coming home for Christmas with Helen and the baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: al 48 "The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 38.

dialogues.speaker: SALINGER
dialogues.text: Hell, bring ‘em along Grandpa. Kay would think she'd died and gone to heaven if there was a baby around. Oe OF Notices a framed photo on the cadenza behind Gene's desk. SALINGER (cont'd) Christ, is that Alaska? The two of them in fly-fishing gear, all smiles, holding up for the camera beside a wild river. Salinger picks it SALINGER (cont'd) Good times, huh?

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: The best. Gene's still guarded, upset. Salinger sets the photo back down on the cadenza, considers Gene.

dialogues.speaker: SALINGER
dialogues.text: I can't have you challenging me in front of senior staff. They respect you. When you question my judgement, you undermine my leadership. If you disagree with a decision I've made, I need you to bring it up with me in private. Gene watches him, at least now he knows why Salinger's he SALINGER (cont'd) There are going to be more difficult decisions ahead. I need to know I can count on your full support. Salinger's gotten deadly serious. Gene knows what's being asked of him. Takes a long moment before finally, nodding Salinger smiles broadly, relieved. Drains his scotch. SALINGER (cont'd) Good. I've always hated single malt scotch. Don't know how you drink it. And with that, he goes, leaving the bottle. Off Gene --

dialogues.speaker: GENE'S KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Cynthia drops her briefcase off on the granite counter, l to the open patio door. Steps outside onto --  49 “The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 39.

dialogues.speaker: THE PATIO
dialogues.text: Gene's on the patio. His tie's loose, Salinger's now half empty bottle of single malt on the table beside him. The yard reaches down to the water, a pier visible beyond.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: You okay? He just keeps staring out to the pier and the water below She waits for a moment, then gives up, starts back inside

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Had lunch with Bobby Walker, I thought he was going to throw a drink in my face.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: He's young. He'll be alright. Gene doesn't respond. She watches him, then: CYNTHIA (cont'd) You were his boss Gene, not his father. Still nothing, the distance between them is painful. CYNTHIA (cont'd) Sue and I are talking about sneaking down to Miami for a weekend later this month. Some shopping, a little golf? Think you could slip away? Christ. He looks off, annoyed. She sees it. CYNTHIA (cont'd) Fine, we'll go without you. She starts back inside again. He calls after her.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Stock closed up two more today. My options are worth half-a-million dollars more than when I woke up this morning. But there's no joy in it. She smiles, missing his meaning

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: That's great, sweetheart. Disappears back into the house leaving Gene, very alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: eH  50 51 52 “The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 40.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL'S GTX OFFICE
dialogues.text: Phil works at his messy desk. He's pale, exhausted. His assistant, NAN, old school, sixties, appears in the door.

dialogues.speaker: NAN
dialogues.text: Need me to stay, Mr. Woodward?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: No, thanks Nan. See you tomorrow. He goes back to work. After a beat, he glances up to see gather her sweater off the back of her chair, retrieve he purse from a drawer. Turn off her desk lamp. Go. Returns to his work. Scratching notes onto a much used yellow pad, referencing a pile of big black spiral binder Stops again. Pushes his glasses up onto his forehead. Rub his eyes. Takes a moment, grabs his empty coffee mug. * Stands. Walks out into the --

dialogues.speaker: SHIP SYSTEMS MARKETING BULLPEN
dialogues.text: Looks down the row of cubicles standing lonely sentinel * outside office doors. * They're all empty. No papers, no photos, no plants or Pos Its. Computers dark. The cubicles cleaned out. Their occupants are never coming back. We PULL GENTLY BACK to REVEAL Phil's outer office, the on surviving outpost in a shadowed corporate wasteland. Off Phil, standing there alone in the immense empty space we

dialogues.speaker: AUTUMN TREES
dialogues.text: It's cold, wet. Beautiful red and yellow maples line Bobb street, the green of September having given way to late October browns and umbers. Bobby and Maggie shepherd a costumed Carson and Drew towa the Volvo. Carson is a pink princess, carries a plastic pumpkin for gathering candy. Drew has a grotesque, head- split by an ax, mask pushed up on his forehead so he can

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Don't eat all the candy you get at school. Three pieces, that's it.

dialogues.speaker: CCONTTNURD 1
dialogues.text: “Phe Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 41.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: (admiring Drew's mask) God, that's disgusting. The kids climb into the Volvo.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I called Bridget, made an appointment.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: who?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: The realtor. Bobby looks off, irritated. She continues, carefully. MAGGIE (cont'd) We should at least list it, see if we get any offers.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: We're not selling the house.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: We don't have to accept an offer. But with the market so bad, it may take us a while to sell if we get stuck.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: We're not going to get stuck. They take a moment, neither giving in. Then: BOBBY (cont'd) How do I look?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Highly employable. He kisses her on the cheek, starts around the Volvo. MAGGIE (cont'd) Bridget?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: We're not selling the house. She wants to say more. Doesn't. Climbs into the Volvo, checks the kids' seat belts. Pulls out, revealing:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 52 53 “The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 42.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Bobby standing beside his Porsche, polished to. perfectio He throws his briefcase in back, climbs in.

dialogues.speaker: NEW GTX CORPORATE HEADQUARTERS BUILDING SITE
dialogues.text: A towering steel superstructure rises up from the bustle the city below. Gene and Salinger are inside the wire cag of a construction elevator as it crawls up the outer edge the building's skeletal frame. Massive raw metal beams gl past. Archer, Stevens, GTX General Counsel, HANSEN.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Lipton bought how much?

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: SEC filing says 3.8 percent.

dialogues.speaker: STEVENS
dialogues.text: He's just trying to goose our stock. He gets it up ten a share, he can walk away with a couple hundred million in profit. *

dialogues.speaker: PROJECT MANAGER
dialogues.text: (as the elevator slows) Hard hats gentlemen. They pull hard hats on, follow the Project Manager into a expansive, open floor of the building.

dialogues.speaker: SALINGER
dialogues.text: Lipton doesn't want a couple hundred * million, he wants the company. *

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Our share price is still too low. It's * making us too tempting a target. * No walls, no windows, only poured concrete and the steel above and below.

dialogues.speaker: SALINGER
dialogues.text: Paul, your office is over there.

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: Whole floor legal?

dialogues.speaker: SALINGER
dialogues.text: No. This floor is just for the five of * us. David, CFO's office. Noah, there. Salinger's enjoying himself, pointing. The Emperor granti tracts of newly conquered land to his favored generals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 53 54 "The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09. 43.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: SALINGER (cont'd) Conference rooms. Private dining rooms, bathrooms with showers. Gym, kitchen. The men grin, migrate to their designated areas, awed by their benefactor's benevolence. Only Gene stands unmoved. Salinger nudges Gene across a skeletal aluminum threshold into an immense corner space. . SALINGER (cont'd) Gene, this is you. Two story openings where the windows will be, expansive v of the city and countryside beyond. It's huge. SALINGER (cont'd) Don't get too excited, my office is going to be much bigger. (turns back to the others) So, what do you think? Salinger moves off to collect the grateful thanks of his executive courtiers. Gene looks around the massive space. Shakes his head, smiles in spite of himself --

dialogues.speaker: HUMAN RESOURCES RECEPTION AREA
dialogues.text: Bobby waits on an uncomfortable couch, leafing through an ancient Forbes. He's been here a while. Looks at his watc frustrated. Heads for the receptionist. She has an orange bucket of Halloween candy on her desk.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Do you know how much longer she's going to be? My appointment was for eleven.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. She's still in her meeting. If you'd like me to interrupt her, I can. Bobby considers. Is that a good idea? Probably not.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: No, that's okay. I'll wait. He sorts through the magazines looking for something he hasn't read yet. Settles on an old People.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Walker? A large woman jammed into a suit several sizes too small.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 54 55 "The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 44.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ROBERTSON (CONT'D) (cont'd) Joyce Robertson. Staff meeting ran over. Sorry to keep you waiting. She doesn't sound all that sorry, but Bobby puts on his g face. Follows her into her small, unimpressive --

dialogues.speaker: ROBERTSON
dialogues.text: Okay if I eat? I have another meeting in a few minutes. She has a salad in Tupperware, a Diet Coke.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Sure, go right ahead. She wasn't waiting for his approval. Finds his resume.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERTSON
dialogues.text: So, you were at GTX twelve years?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Divisional sales leader three of the twelve.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERTSON
dialogues.text: I'm surprised they let you go.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Yeah, well. So was I.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERTSON
dialogues.text: Have you handled regional sales?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I came up in regional sales. I was in California with Martin-Marietta before moving here with GTX. He's trying hard, smiling, accommodating. It's a little l on her, she hasn't looked up from her salad.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERTSON
dialogues.text: We're looking to expand in the South; we need someone in Little Rock.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Arkansas?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERTSON
dialogues.text: Is relocation a problem?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: "The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 45. 55

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: No. I had hoped to remain in the area, I grew up here.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERTSON
dialogues.text: You left the salary requirements space blank on your application. He shifts uncomfortably, maintains that salesman's smile.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Well, that's negotiable of course... I was making a hundred and twenty at GTX. (floats a number) I'd be willing to accept one ten to start. Hope for bonuses. That gets her nose up out of her salad.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERTSON
dialogues.text: Our base salary is sixty-five a year for regional sales directors. It's getting harder for him to maintain that smile.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I responded to your ad for the Vice- President of Marketing.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERTSON
dialogues.text: We've had a number of highly qualified applicants for that position.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Lady, I'm a highly qualified applicant for that position. They stare at each other. Finally, Bobby stands: BOBBY (cont'd) Sorry, I probably had too much coffee waiting in your reception area for over two fucking hours. He starts for the door. Stops, turns back. BOBBY (cont'd) Oh, and you know what? You can skip the Diet Coke. It ain't helping.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 56 “The Company Men" Shooting Draft Pinks 4/13/09 46.

dialogues.speaker: AN UPSCALE HOTEL BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Afternoon sun sneaks through the partially closed drapes. Flowers, antiques, wool carpeting. It's nice, expensive. Gene sits propped up in the sheets of the dishevelled bed talking to someone we can't see.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Jim's worried, thinks we're a target.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN, (0S)
dialogues.text: Lipton can put together that kind of money in the middle of a recession?

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: It's what he does.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN, (0S)
dialogues.text: So then what, he splits us up? A toilet flushes off screen.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Sells off the health care unit and rail 8, closes Gloucester. He'd still have consumer electronics, the turbine and defense units, boom. ...We're a bargain now. Sally Wilcox steps out of the bathroom, silk slip, lace b Begins pulling her clothes off the back of a chair. GENE (cont'd) Hell, stock's been flat for so long, we miss another quarter Lipton’1l be able to round up enough votes to wage a proxy fight. Install his own board. She wiggles into her skirt, pulls on her Anne Fontaine blouse, slip into her heels. He watches, it's very sexy. GENE (cont'd) But Jim won't go down without a fight, I'm sure he's already out there looking for a white knight. Roberts or maybe Keets, somebody with deep pockets. He stops, staring off, lost in the possible scenarios. Sh watches him, smiles. He notices. GENE (cont'd) what? She leans in close, bites at his lip playfully, whispers: (CONTTNITED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 47.

dialogues.speaker: WILCOX
dialogues.text: Don't stop. Tell me again about capital depreciation of manufacturing assets. He smiles, plays along.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Straight-line or declining balance...? She moans seductively, kisses his face, neck.

dialogues.speaker: WILCOX
dialogues.text: -.-both, please...

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Well, capital assets have to be deducted over the number of years that you anticipate the asset will be in use -~

dialogues.speaker: WILCOX
dialogues.text: -+-uh-huh... She's moved from his neck onto his chest, kissing him gen running her fingertips lighting over his skin.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: But the problem with heavy manufacturing assets is determining the length of time ...the assets...will be in service... He's having trouble concentrating as she works her way sl onto his stomach, his eyes closing. GENE (cont'd) +..To get an un-depreciated salvage value...for when it's sold or scrapped... Her hand wanders under the sheet. A beat and then her BLACKBERRY goes off. She hesitates, smiles at him. He smirks as if to say "don't". But she does. Sits up, pulls the Blackberry from her bag, reads it.

dialogues.speaker: WILCOX
dialogues.text: My office. I have senior staff at three.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Reschedule. She smiles, stands. Finishes buttoning her blouse. GENE (cont'd) Lunch again next Tuesday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 56 57 58 “The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 48.

dialogues.speaker: WILCOX
dialogues.text: Maybe... But she's coming, she always does. Pulls on her jacket, leans it to kiss him a final time, goes. Gene sits in the rumpled bed, staring at the back of the hotel door, exhal

dialogues.speaker: THE COUNTRY CLUB DRIVING RANGE
dialogues.text: We MOVE ALONG a weekday afternoon line of golfers poundin balls out into the range, retirees mostly, two-tone shoes colorful slacks and pullover sweaters, to FIND: Bobby. Dress shirt, loosened tie, suit-pants. His suit jacket hangs unceremoniously from his golf bag behind him He's pulled on golf shoes, has worked his way about halfw through a large basket of balls beside him. TWHACK! A ball goes flying off. Puts another down, and TWHACK! Doesn't watch where it goes, doesn't care. Sets down another and TWHACK! His face contorted, sweating. He taking out his fury on the balls. WHACK! TWACK! As we --

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. GTX FOXBOUROUGH SKYBOX
dialogues.text: Lake, Jane and other sales execs schmooze clients while t Pats grind it out on the field below. Well-stocked bar. Nachos and steak fajitas, chili and chips.

dialogues.speaker: OLSON
dialogues.text: I, can't recommend a new half-a-billion dollar boat to my Board when I'm not even sure you'll be around in a year. Phil sits with an exec, MARK OLSON, in the seats down fro

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: We're not going anywhere. Closing two shipyards allowed us to move our best people up here to Gloucester.

dialogues.speaker: OLSON
dialogues.text: Rumor is Salinger doesn't even want to be in the ship building business anymore.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Bullshit. Nobody else has our history of quality workmanship, our skilled labor : force, and nobody can guarantee delivery on your timeline. Nagasaki? If they're (MORE) (CONTTNITED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 58 59 "The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 49.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: PHIL (cont'd) saying they can, they're lying. They're already behind on Disney's new boat.

dialogues.speaker: OLSON
dialogues.text: Look, I've always liked you Phil. But Lipton is making a lot of noise about selling Gloucester if he buys you guys. I recommend this deal to my board and then you get sold to the Japanese or shut down, I look like a fucking idiot. Olson stands, heads for the bar. Lake watches him pass, slides into Olson's empty seat expectantly.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: He's nervous.

dialogues.speaker: LAKE
dialogues.text: No shit. We all are. They stare out at the game. Off Phil --

dialogues.speaker: MK
dialogues.text: We MOVE ABOVE the tiny carrels, each one filled with an unemployed exec working the phones, making lists. An air quiet desperation in the air. FIND Bobby on the phone, jeans, sweater, coffee cup. Danny's next to him, scanning job sites on the internet. Diane stuffs envelopes. Conal' on Bobby's other side, playing solitaire on his computer.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Robert Walker. Jim Tetlow told me to call. I sent my resume three weeks ago. (checks his notes) I'll be travelling on business in the Milwaukee area on the tenth or eleventh so I could stop by and see him then. Danny grimaces, sotto:

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Milwaukee?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Well, then could you tell me who's conducting the search? Bobby takes down the name, a number. It joins the rows of other names and numbers on his overused yellow pad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 59 "The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 50.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BOBBY (cont'd) Thanks for your help. Hangs up. Looks down at what we recognize as Gene's list names. All but four are crossed off, a few notes are jott in the margin "after lst", "Spring", “back 11/26".

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Headhunter?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Yeah, in San Francisco no less.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: How convenient. Bobby rubs his forehead. Looks down at his now messy litt desk top, shuffles around his handwritten lists, dials.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Jonas Geller's office please. (waits) Hi, this is Robert Walker, is he available?... No, he doesn't know me, Mike Talbot at Unicor mentioned that Mr. Geller might be looking for a senior sales... Oh, it was... Yeah, thanks... Hangs up. Crosses that one off too. Shuffles through the rest of his dog-eared lists. "BU", "Chicago", "Sigma Nu", “Bussman". The lists are marked up, names crossed out, doodled on. Starts another call.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Sixty-five bucks an hour for oil rig workers in the North Atlantic. Extra thousand a week if you have your commercial deep-sea diver certification.

dialogues.speaker: CONAL
dialogues.text: Doesn't everybody?

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: I got mine last year at the Y. (looking at Conal's screen) Six of clubs on the seven of hearts.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: (into phone) Sally Wilcox please...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 51.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Highway construction, hazardous waste removal, aircraft mechanic. Thank god I got that Doctorate, huh?

dialogues.speaker: CONAL
dialogues.text: How long'd you work at Hughes?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Twenty-two years.

dialogues.speaker: CONAL
dialogues.text: They give you a reason?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Globalization, outsourcing, the declining yuan. We're all part of the new world economy man, don't you read Newsweek?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Hi, yeah. It's Bobby Walker calling. Is she in? (a beat) Sure, give me her voice mail.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: He calling her again?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Sally, it's Bob Walker. Nice of you to never return my phone calls. If you ever do call me back I just want to ask you why you fucking fired me without any notice, you cowardly bitch. He SLAMS the phone down in the receiver. Danny grins.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Gee, I wonder why she never calls back?

dialogues.speaker: CONAL
dialogues.text: Twenty-two years, Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: My father worked for the Pennsylvania Railroad for thirty-five.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Mine delivered mail for forty.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: My Dad's been selling plumbing supplies in Woburn since 1974. Same office, same (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . “The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 52.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BOBBY (cont'd) boss, eating the same shitty sack lunch behind his desk every day.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I don't know, always seemed to me like my Dad had a great life; steady job, pension, new car every other year.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: All depends on what you're willing to settle for I guess. Danny watches Bobby carefully, then stands, announcing:

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Know what I think? I think it's quitting time.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: A man can only take so much rejection. I'm thirsty. Who's coming? Danny's already pulling on his coat. Looks to Conal. DANNY (cont'd) Conal? Conal sneaks a guilty look to Bobby. Then:

dialogues.speaker: CONAL
dialogues.text: Sure. The two conspirators look to Diane.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: I'm in. Now they all look to Bobby. He hesitates, unsure. Then:

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Why the hell not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby pulls his Porsche into the driveway to find Maggie the garage, unloading groceries from the Volvo. He climbs out, spots Drew sitting sullenly on the curb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 60 "The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 53.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Christ, you smell like a brewery.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: What's Drew doing sitting out there?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Waiting for you.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I think he's worried about you.

dialogues.speaker: AT CURB
dialogues.text: Bobby walks down the driveway. Drew can hear him coming b doesn't turn. Kids play on their bikes down the street.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Hey, what are you doing out here? Drew doesn't answer. Bobby joins him on the curb. BOBBY (cont'd) You okay?

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: I'm not a baby, I can handle stuff. Bobby takes a deep breath, Christ:

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I lost my job. Drew stops, looks back at him, it's not what he expected. BOBBY (cont'd) What'd you think it was?

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: You and Mom maybe. Bobby shakes, "no". Drew stands there, considering. DREW (cont'd) You'll get another one, right?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: A job? You bet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 60 61 62 "The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 54.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Maggie returns for the last of groceries. Stops, watches her husband and son, talking in the fading afternoon ligh

dialogues.speaker: HERB RITTENOUR, (VO)
dialogues.text: Billionaire investor Arthur Lipton today stepped up his campaign for changes at GTX, issuing a letter to shareholders - Gene sits at his desk, staring at the financial news on T HERB RITTENOUR (cont'd) Accusing executives of mismanagement and demanding new shareholder representation on the Board. Last week Lipton urged GTX to sell it's Healthcare subsidiary - Karen steps in from her desk outside to watch. HERB RITTENOUR (cont'd) - as a way to help lift GTX's share price. He also criticized expenditures on GTX's new headquarters building under construction in... Phil drifts in now too, ashen. Stares at the screen.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: What does it all mean?

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Nothing good. Sees Phil standing numb, frozen halfway into the room. GENE (cont'd) You need something Phil?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: We lost Royal Caribbean.

dialogues.speaker: WALKER HOUSE DINING ROOM
dialogues.text: Bobby's parents' home. A working class house in Framingha The table's set with family china and crystal for the adu paper and plastic for the kids. But not formal, beer bott mingle with water glasses. Everyone's settling in around table; Jack, Bobby and Drew. Bobby's mother, FRAN, comes (CONTTNITED )

dialogues.speaker: OOF
dialogues.text: 62 “The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 55.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
