dialogues.text: from the kitchen, carrying more food, followed by Jack's wife, Diedre.

dialogues.speaker: FRAN
dialogues.text: Drew, round up your cousins.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: How's business, Jack? KEVIN WALKER, Bobby's father, sixty.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Doing a big renovation in Roxbury, next to that house I did last year. Nice bonus when I finish it by September.

dialogues.speaker: DIEDRE
dialogues.text: If you finish it by September.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Whenever you're ready to plumb the place, give me a call, got a special on Kohler.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: How's work, Bobby? Line up more dollar-a- day Laotian preschoolers to stitch tennis shoes for you in Bangkok? Kevin smiles. Bobby doesn't. Drew and his cousins run bac from the yard, make their way to the table. The room is chaotic. Kids, food making it's way to the table, a big s bowl is being passed around, a basket of fresh baked roll

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I'm in manufacturing, Jack. Laotian _ preschoolers aren't tall enough to tighten the bolts on diesel engines.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I was reading about your guy Salinger in the Globe the other day.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: You're reading now?

dialogues.speaker: JBCK
dialogues.text: When they use small words. Said he made seven hundred times what the average GTX worker made last year. (Bobby tries to ignore him) What do you think? Salinger working seven hundred times harder than a welder pounding hot rivets into a tanker hull?

dialogues.speaker: OOF
dialogues.text: 62 63 "The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 56.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Maggie appears with cranberries, Diedre follows with grav

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Can we say grace so the kids can start? Maggie swats gently at Drew who's already trying to eat.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Carson, would you do the honors? All slowly link hands, bow their heads.

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: Dear God, thank you for the food and for letting us be together on Thanksgiving and for everybody being okay. (is she done/thinks) And please help my Dad find a job, so he won't be unhappy all the time. Amen. You could hear a pin drop. Kevin stares at his son, so do Fran. Jack grins sheepishly to Diedre... holy shit.

dialogues.speaker: WALKER LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Bobby stands in the big picture window, looking out into yard where his father burns leaves by the garage and the play a rowdy game of touch football.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Things get tough, I could always use some extra help this winter. Bobby looks back at him, what?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Hanging drywall?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: They'll be lots of work, four thousand square feet. We're gutting the place. It was hard for Jack to offer.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Thanks Jack, but I can't really see myself pounding nails. Bobby goes. Jack watches him as he steps outside, walks across the yard toward his father. What an asshole --  64 65 “The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 57.

dialogues.speaker: WALKER YARD
dialogues.text: Bobby walks through Drew and his cousins playing football

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Dad, you wanna play?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Maybe later, okay? Drew stares after him, disappointed. Bobby steps up to hi father and the burning leaves. BOBBY (CONT'D) (cont'd) They downsized a couple hundred of us here, thousands more company wide. His father doesn't look up. The smoke rises into a leaden sky, heavy with a coming snow.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Early September.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN -
dialogues.text: That big house in Wellesley, the cars, the ski vacations. Christ, the way you two live.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: (angrily) . I'm irresponsible, living beyond my means. Right, Dad?’ They stare at each other over the pile of leaves.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: Your mom and I. have some money put away -- Bobby shakes his head, no. As the kids play football, we

dialogues.speaker: GTX BOARDROOM
dialogues.text: A huge granite conference table set with crystal water carafes and Mont Blanc pens. Salinger's at the head of th table, Gene is there, Archer, Stevens and Hansen.

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: Goldman Sachs is doing due diligence for Lipton and Skadden Arps is snooping around for somebody, maybe Allied, maybe (MORE) (CONTTNITED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 58.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: HANSEN (cont'd) Simonov's Baltic Global out of Moscow. Bater Woodruff called, off the record. Gene looks up, Allied? Really?

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: What's the top price Bater'll pay?

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: 89 a share.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Too low.

dialogues.speaker: STEVENS
dialogues.text: Doesn't matter. When it got out that Belcon Capital was looking at Ocean » Steel, shares jumped ten.

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: Lipton's put market value at one hundred.

dialogues.speaker: SALINGER
dialogues.text: So we need our stock at one hundred two. That get's everyone's heads up out of their papers. A bea

dialogues.speaker: STEVENS
dialogues.text: That's seventeen more a share.

dialogues.speaker: SALINGER
dialogues.text: I can add, Noah.

dialogues.speaker: STEVENS
dialogues.text: We're already in danger of not making our quarterly. We start fooling around and miss our numbers again -~

dialogues.speaker: SALINGER
dialogues.text: We don't have to get all the way to one hundred. It gets into the mid-nineties we'll show we're on a positive trend.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: How are we supposed to boost the share price again? Salinger takes a beat, knows it's not going to go down we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Increased efficiencies, reduced costs.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: More downsizing?

dialogues.speaker: CCONTTNITED Y
dialogues.text: 65 “The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 59.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The room quiets. Salinger looks at Gene, a warning. GENE (cont'd) What happens if we try this stunt again and the stock stalls at ninety?

dialogues.speaker: SALINGER
dialogues.text: Increasing market value isn't a "stunt". It's now so quiet you can hear the hiss of forced air hea rushing through vents. But Gene presses on:
GENE ‘ We should at least explore other options. (no one speaks up) What about selling the Healthcare group?

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Maybe Lipton is right.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Healthcare is the only division exhibiting growth.

dialogues.speaker: SALINGER
dialogues.text: I'm not breaking the company up.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: All right. What about selling the new headquarters building?

dialogues.speaker: STEVENS
dialogues.text: You've seen our future occupancy studies, we're going to need the space.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Not if we keep firing people, we're not.

dialogues.speaker: SALINGER
dialogues.text: I'm not selling the new building! It's an eruption. It silences the room. After a few uncomfortable beats, Salinger turns to Hansen. SALINGER (cont'd) Tell Human Resources to start drawing up a list for another round of downsizing.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 66 "The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 60.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Jim... Jim...! Gene catches up to Salinger and Archer walking in the gla walled boardroom hallway. Salinger doesn't slow. GENE (cont'd) gim, come on... Salinger slows reluctantly. Archer's still there. GENE (cont'd) Give us a minute, would you? (Archer moves off) What do you want me to do, parrot back everything you say? (Salinger stiffens) I've always told you what I thought, right or wrong. And this is wrong. f SALINGER, I'm late for a meeting. And Salinger goes. Off Gene, left alone in the hallway, w

dialogues.speaker: 66A OMIT / 66A
dialogues.text: 67 "The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 61.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY'S BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Bobby and Maggie in bed, talking quietly under the sheets the dark. It's late, snowing lightly outside.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: We won't be able to make the mortgage next month. I called Bridget, she thinks if we price the house low enough, we may be able to get as much as four hundred.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Four hundred? That's less than we owe. We'd loose everything we've got in it.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter how much we've got in it, your severance ends in three weeks. We're going to end up in foreclosure. They're not fighting, both are too tired, her head restin his outstretched arm.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: We won't have anything to put down on another house.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: We can't qualify for a new house on just my salary anyway.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: So what are we supposed to do, pitch a tent in the park? Maggie takes a beat, knows this is going to go down badly

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: We could move in with your folks.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Oh, shit...

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: They have two extra bedrooms --

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: We're not moving in with my parents.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: It'd just be temporary.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I'd have to kill myself first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 67  "The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 62.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They lay there like that for a long beat.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Jack told me he offered you a job the other day and you shut him down pretty hard.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Can't you see that, me working for your brother?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: He was just trying to help.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: By letting me hang drywall? Maggie stares at him, is he really that removed from real She tries a different tack --

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You'd get back into great shape. She traces her finger along his hand, up his arm, it's se MAGGIE (cont'd) Callouses, a tan.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: In the middle of winter?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Big, broad shoulders from carrying all that heavy lumber and the hammering... She's trying, but he isn't responding. Then, quietly:

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I have to get up early. Turns away from her, pulls up the covers. She's left layi there staring at the ceiling. Rejected, as we -~

dialogues.speaker: THE UPSCALE HOTEL ROOM
dialogues.text: Wilcox's head lies on Gene's naked chest, post-coital, ba under the sheets at their every~Tuesday lunch hotel.

dialogues.speaker: WILCOX
dialogues.text: Bobby Walker's still leaving me messages. My assistant thinks he's psychotic, wants me to get a restraining order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 68 "The Company Men” Shooting Draft 3/30/09 63.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: I'm sure you've gotten worse. She looks at him. Yeah she has, but she doesn't need to h it from him. After a moment:

dialogues.speaker: WILCOX
dialogues.text: Think you'll be able to get away for a day or two of skiing at Christmas? Gene looks at her, what? After a beat, carefully:

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: I don't know. I'1l1 have to see. (changing the subject) Hansen get you started on the new list? She eyes him, isn't sure they should be discussing this. GENE (cont'd) I was in the meeting, Sally.

dialogues.speaker: WILCOX
dialogues.text: Yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: How many? (she doesn't answer) How many?

dialogues.speaker: WILCOX
dialogues.text: Five thousand.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: What's the criteria for getting canned this time? Hell, Gary Hunt's put ona few extra pounds, maybe he should go. Heard Jill Carter has cancer, we could save a bundle on her insurance premiums. She stares at him, doesn't answer, climbs out of bed, hun for her lingerie on the floor. Gene takes a breath -- shi GENE (cont'd) Sally... Nothing, her back to him, pulling on her clothing. He reaches across, gently touches her back, but she stands, disappears into the bathroom. Off Gene --

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 69 70 “The Company Men” Shooting Draft 3/30/09 64.

dialogues.speaker: THE. COUNTRY CLUB
dialogues.text: A bright, crisp, early winter day. Bobby heads for the diehards hitting balls onto the brown grass of the range.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Hey, the billionaire boy's club, how goes the plotting? Warren Buffet still safe atop the Fortune five hundred? Mifflin, Conners, and Carlson look among themselves uncomfortably, were clearly talking about Bobby.

dialogues.speaker: CONNERS
dialogues.text: How's the job hunt going, Bobby?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Terrific. A young country club employee, DALE, arrives.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Mr. Conners, your group is up. They gather themselves, start for the first tee.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Ready to get your ass kicked, Eric?

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: -.-Mr. Walker? Dale discreetly motions for Bobby to wait as the others s out. Bobby looks at him quizzically. DALE (cont'd) Can I speak to you for a moment?

dialogues.speaker: MASS GENERAL
dialogues.text: Bobby makes his way down the hospital hall, looking. Dodg patients, staff. Spots Maggie. behind a nurses' station.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: What the hell is going on? Uh-oh, she doesn't like the sound of that. BOBBY (cont'd) I got thrown off the course at the Club! She pulls him aside in the hallway, tries to calm him dow (CONTTNITED 1)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 70 “The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 65.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Keep your voice down.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: We haven't paid our dues since October?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I haven't been paying a lot of things.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I looked like a fucking deadbeat! She's not going to stand there while he yells at her. Ste up to him, toe to toe.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: This is real, Bobby. This is happening to us. But you're wandering around in some sort of a daze. Playing golf? Getting your Porsche detailed?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I have to look successful! I can't just be another asshole with a resume!

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You are just another asshole with a resume! He stops, stares at her. She looks down, didn't mean it t come out quite like that. He stares off defiantly, then:

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I wrote them a check for the balance.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Cancel it. Bobby, turns. Walks away.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: We can't afford it!

dialogues.speaker: NO
dialogues.text: cUT TO:  71 “The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 66.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: Maggie pulls in. Has to park in the driveway. The garage a mess of boxes and junk, Bobby in the middle of it, sort

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: T should have been honest with you about the club, but you haven't been honest with me.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Do we need this anymore? An old, much used playpen. She doesn't answer. BOBBY (cont'd) Figured we'd throw a garage sale this weekend. Maybe raise a couple of bucks. He's cold, distant. Rummages through junk.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You need to get a job, any job. (he doesn't answer) I can't do this alone, Bobby.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: You're right. I'm playing golf at the club and in a few weeks I won't be able to support my family. Self-pity isn't what she was hoping for.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: We're going to get through this. Things will be great again. He heaves a stack of baby toys into the pile angrily.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Things won't be great again. I've been looking for months and I haven't had one job offer, not one. I've called everybody I know and a lot of people I don't and begged, fucking begged for a job, a lead, anything! (and) There are thousands of new MBAs out there who will work for nothing. No kids, no mortgage! Work ninety-hour weeks! (then) You want honesty? I'm a thirty-seven year old unemployed fuck-up who can't even support his own family! (CONT TNURD )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 71 72 "The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 67.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: That's not true. You're gonna find a job, a good job. Working for people who know how lucky they are to have you. Tears stream down his face, he wipes them away angrily.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Christ, when did it all turn to shit? Now she's wiping away tears too.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: It hasn't turned to shit. You have Drew and Carson. Your parents. And me...you have me. He stands there, all shattered pride and rage as Carson r her bike up into the drive, handlebar streamers flutterin the breeze. Stops, not wanting to intrude, watches quietl cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: HUMAN RESOURCES CONFERENCE ROOM
dialogues.text: Gene, Wilcox, Landry, Hansen. Donuts, coffee. Gene's * staring at a long list. Shifts uncomfortably in his chair

dialogues.speaker: WILCOX
dialogues.text: Debra Hayes has ten years with the company and outstanding evaluations.

dialogues.speaker: LANDRY
dialogues.text: She also has a husband with a successful law practice and two kids who'd probably be delighted to have Mommy at home.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: She's sixty, I doubt her "kids" are still in school, much less calling her Mommy. (and) Phil Woodward's on here again. Gene's staring at Wilcox. lLandry looks around, answers.

dialogues.speaker: LANDRY
dialogues.text: He fits the criteria --

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: I wasn't talking to you, Dick. It's tough, meant to shut Landry up. It doesn't. *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “The Company Men" Shooting Draft Yellows 5/4/09 68.

dialogues.speaker: LANDRY
dialogues.text: He's grossly overpaid and just blew a five hundred million dollar deal -~-

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: What are you, deaf? Shut the fuck up. (back to Wilcox) The Royal Caribbean thing wasn't his fault, they were frightened away by all the takeover talk.

dialogues.speaker: WILCOX
dialogues.text: We did a thorough cost/productivity evaluation of each employee, examined numerous indices --

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Cut the Harvard Business school bullshit and take him off the goddam list. She's shocked, a deer in the headlights, looks to Hansen support. Hansen leans forward to Gene, proceeds evenly.

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: The list is still preliminary, Gene. Gene is leafing through it, incredulous.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: I'm looking and all I see are people over fifty with just enough young ones thrown in to protect us against litigation. Hansen stares flatly at Gene.

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: I'm confident all of these dismissals will stand up to outside legal scrutiny.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: What about ethical scrutiny?

dialogues.speaker: HANSEN
dialogues.text: We're not breaking any laws, Gene. (CONTTNUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “The Company Men" Shooting Draft Yellows 5/4/09 69.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Gene takes a moment, considers Hansen:

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: I guess I always assumed we were trying for a higher standard than that, Paul.

dialogues.speaker: ONE COMMUNICATIONS HUMAN RESOURCES DEPARTMENT
dialogues.text: Bobby waits in the reception area, suit, tie. Pessimistic wishing he were somewhere else. Checks his watch.

dialogues.speaker: THAYER
dialogues.text: Mr. Walker? A man Bobby's age, friendly, warm, informal. THAYER (cont'd) Troy Thayer. 74  ‘HAYER'S OFFICE 74 Kid's photos and drawings, messy desk. Thayer motions Bob to the couch, sits in a chair. Hunts for Bobby's file,

dialogues.speaker: THAYER
dialogues.text: A GTX casualty. How you holding up?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Okay, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: THAYER
dialogues.text: Dan Mass gave you a great recommendation. (veading) Sales, marketing, MBA. Regional work. You went to school at State College?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Undergrad, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: THAYER
dialogues.text: My wife went to Penn, loved it. Bobby looks at him, a real human being? Is that possible? THAYER (cont'd) You willing to work for ninety a year plus commission and bonus?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: A...yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 74 15 “The Company Men" Shooting Draft Pinks 4/13/09 70.

dialogues.speaker: THAYER
dialogues.text: Good news is we're growing fast and there's plenty of head room around here. Thayer closes the file, offers his hand. THAYER (cont'd) I can't promise you anything, but with Dan's recommendation and your resume, you seem like the right £ fit for the job. (steers Bobby out) We have to make a decision by next week, so you should hear from us soon. cur 70:

dialogues.speaker: GENE'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: Gene's at his desk, staring out at the wintery exurbia. A woman's angry voice intrudes.

dialogues.speaker: WILCOX
dialogues.text: What the hell was that?

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: What the hell was "what"?

dialogues.speaker: WILCOX
dialogues.text: You humiliated me in front of Hansen.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: You put Phil on the list?

dialogues.speaker: WILCOX
dialogues.text: We can hire three workers for the same money we're paying Phil Woodward.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: So loyalty and experience mean nothing?

dialogues.speaker: WILCOX
dialogues.text: You're not the one who has to tell three other employees they' re getting fired so you can keep Phil.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: So don't do it.

dialogues.speaker: WILCOX
dialogues.text: Don't do what, my job? Is that what you're asking? (CONTTNORD)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 15 76 “The Company Men" Shooting Draft Pinks 4/13/09 71.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Gene takes a beat, then:

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I guess it is. Wilcox stares at him. Then, simply:

dialogues.speaker: WILCOX
dialogues.text: I'm forty years old, single. You gonna leave your wife when I get canned? Marry me. Help me get back on my feet? She waits, he doesn't answer. WILCOX (cont'd) That's what I thought. She turns, leaves. Off Gene -- cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: THE BOSTON COMMON
dialogues.text: Bobby makes his way across the street, dodging traffic an dirty snow. Heads into the park to find Danny, Diane and others from outplacement playing five on five, out-of-sha touch football in the cold. Conal's on the sidelines, bundled up, guarding the beers.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Who's winning?

dialogues.speaker: CONAL
dialogues.text: Who knows. How'd it go?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: The interview? Not bad. Bobby strips off his suit~jacket, loosens his tie. Heads the game, yelling to the players. (CONTTNTITED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 716 77 "The Company Men" Shooting Draft Pinks 4/13/09 72.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BOBBY (cont'd) Anybody need an All-Pro wideout?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yeah, we're getting our asses kicked.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: You can take my place... Bobby joins Danny's team as Diane jogs back to the picnic table. Danny steps in behind center, taking the hike.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Huht...huht...HUHT! The MIS guy center snaps the ball. Bobby runs like hell o down and out. Diane sits next to Conal, trying to warm up

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: How'd his interview go, he say? Bobby fakes left, goes right. Danny wafts him the bail. H catches it over the outstretched hands of his defender. Spins a move, slips, dives forward for some extra yardage comes up smiling. Muddy, and very happy.

dialogues.speaker: CONAL
dialogues.text: Guess it went okay.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE GENE'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: Gene sits down by the pier, overcoat still on. Drink in hand. Cynthia comes from the house, looking for him.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: What are you doing out here, it's freezing? He takes a beat.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: We're firing more people.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: Could you have stopped it? He doesn't answer, doesn't want to answer. She watches hi then carefully:

dialogues.speaker: CCONTTNTTRD Y
dialogues.text: 77 78 "The Company Men". Shooting Draft 3/30/09 73.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CYNTHIA (cont’d) Why don't you quit? (he looks up, what?) Beth graduates this year, Liam is set. We've got more than enough money to last a couple of lifetimes.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: And do what, garden?

dialogues.speaker: _ CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: We could sell this place. Live out on the Vineyard like we've always wanted to.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: You could learn needlepoint while I try my hand at watercolor landscapes. She's stung. But presses on:

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: Travel, buy a place in Florida or San Remo. Sail, play a little tennis, golf.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: I hate golf. \ She's tired of it, of him. She stares at him for a moment then turns and goes. Off Gene, brooding in his chair in t gathering darkness, barely registering that she's left, w

dialogues.speaker: MK
dialogues.text: Bobby sits in his carrel, staring at the phone. Danny returns from the coffee room, looks to Conal. Conal shake his head, no.. Danny walks across the room toward Bobby, passing people loading up, leaving for the day.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: They'll call tomorrow. Bobby looks up at Danny. Doesn't answer. Stands, gathers his things, pulls on his coat, starts out. Diane steps ou of the Xerox room to watch him pass. . Danny calls after DANNY (cont'd) Hey Bobby. They haven't seen anything yet. We're just getting started. (CONTTNITED )

dialogues.speaker: 80A
dialogues.text: “The Company Men" Shooting Draft Goldenrod 5/15/09 74.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Bobby looks back, smiles. It's not very convincing. Turns pushes through the glass door, and he's gone. *

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: The house is quiet, only a single VOICE offscreen, somewh deep inside. We MOVE towards it, through the silent livin room. MOVE into the hushed stillness of the kitchen and d the stairs to FIND Bobby, his back to us, on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: ...Troy Thayer, please. (listens) Is he in, Robert Walker calling... (a long wait) .-:No, I understand...I was calling about a position. Northeastern Sales Manager. We COME SLOWLY around to his face, the bright winter ligh filtering through the breakfast nook blinds. BOBBY (cont'd) +--It has... (a beat, then) Thank you for your time... He hangs the phone up slowly, leans back against the wall Maggie has appeared on the steps. Watching. After a beat, he looks up, sees her there. Her heart aches for him. He pushes himself off the wall, hands her an envelope as he passes.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: What‘s this?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: My last paycheck. *

dialogues.speaker: OMIT 80
dialogues.text: BOBBY'S GARAGE - LATE NIGHT sOA * Bobby's in the garage, light on overhead, vacuum, Windex, Armoxall, carefully, loyingly, polishing the Porsche in t middle of the night. Off Bobby, solitary, working, we -- cur To:  81 82 83 "the Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 75.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: Bobby stands outside his open garage, remains of a recent snow feathered around the brown grass. Watches Maggie at curb, talking to a young man in a suit, writing a check. (he stares at her) Instead of listing the number of years you held each position at GTX, indicate your title and responsibilities. And here, where you've noted your military service, don't say Vietnam. Combat infantryman is impressive enough. She's marking up his resume like some fourth grade teache JOANNA (cont'd) You could stand to loose a few pounds. You smoke, Phil?

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA

dialogues.text: A bright, blinding post-snow day. It's cold, a brisk wind coming in off the Atlantic. Bobby parks his used Camry in front of an old house. Climbs out. The house is a couple hundred years old, torn up. Stacks of lumber sit in the yard, plastic sheeting covers the windows. Makes his way slowly up the debris strewn drive, past the dumpster and a Sam Gump, out onto the rock hard, frozen d yard, toward the sound of SAWS and HAMMERS. A man comes f the house, heading for a truck. Bobby's bother-in-law, Ja Jack, stares. Tool belt, old flannel shirt, beat-up down vest. Bobby stops a few yards away from him. Clouds of ha white mist escaping with every breath.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I need a job, Jack.

Hammer, tape measurer, screwdrivers. Jack stands by his truck; two men beside him. Davey, muscular, fifties, a lit Camel dangling from his mouth. A MIKE, twenties, silent, hung-over. SLAMS into th front door frame, staggers back, crouches to make it into

Every step is torture, the machined plywood edges cut int his hands, his muscles scream, the precarious drop to the first floor increasingly terrifying with every step. To m matters worse, he SLAMS the plywood on each landing as he climbs. Each SLAM jarring teeth and bones, his head smash against the fresh cut ply. Finally arrives on --

dialogues.speaker: WILCOX
dialogues.text: How long're you going to keep this up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep what up? She stops, angry.

dialogues.speaker: WILCOX
dialogues.text: This. Tonight. Hanging around on my sofa. Feeling sorry for yourself.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: I told you I didn't want to come. She stares at him, then gives up, starts back for the car GENE (cont'd) Five percent on distressed assets and sky diving? Jesus Christ...

dialogues.speaker: CCONTTNURD 1
dialogues.text: 110 111 "The Company Men" Shooting Draft Yellows 5/4/09 94.

dialogues.speaker: WILCOX
dialogues.text: (turns on him) Goddammit! Jim Salinger's a prick, you got screwed, get over it! She continues on, but he doesn't move. Suddenly frozen. Looks up into the dark sky, millions of small drops of ra cascade down toward him, illuminated by streetlights. She realizes he has stopped. Turns back. Sees him standin there. WILCOX (cont'd) Give me the keys. He doesn't answer, still mesmerized. WILCOX (cont'd) You're drunk. (still nothing) Give me the damn keys, Gene! Off Gene, staring up into the dark sky, we --

dialogues.speaker: OMIT 111
dialogues.text: 112 113 114 115 "The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 95.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: Bobby stands in the empty kitchen. No furniture, the kids drawings on the refrigerator, the bulletin board of famil photos and school notices gone. Only a few boxes remain o the counter. Maggie enters, grabs one, followed by Drew w takes another.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You check the basement? He nods. They leave. Bobby grabs the final box off the counter, takes a last look around. And goes. cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY'S PARENTS' HOUSE
dialogues.text: Bobby tucks Drew in, Carson's already asleep in the other twin bed, dog sleeping at her feet. The room is plain, no yet adorned with any of the children's personal belonging BOBBY . You going to be alright sleeping with your sister for awhile? Drew smiles up at his father, nods.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Sure. Drew's so adult, it makes his father want to cry. Bobby steps out into --

dialogues.speaker: THE HALLWAY 114
dialogues.text: Finds his father, climbing the stairs on his way to bed.

dialogues.speaker: KEVIN
dialogues.text: They tucked in? Bobby nods. Kevin stands there, its awkward, distant. KEVIN (cont'd) Need anything? Bobby takes a moment, then shakes his head, "no". Kevin goes. Bobby watches him disappear into his bedroom as we

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY'S OLD BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Bobby stares at the ceiling in the semi-darkness. (CONTTNITED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 115 116 "The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 96.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I couldn't wait to get out of this house. My parents, the neighborhood, the church. He looks around the room, takes a deep breath. Quietly: BOBBY (cont'd) I was going to be CEO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A splendid spring day, tulips and lilacs. Two young child run in the yard, Easter baskets in hand, hunting for eggs

dialogues.speaker: LIAM
dialogues.text: She seems nice, Dad. Good with kids. Wilcox and Gene's daughter-in-law, Susan, point out possi egg locations to the kids. Gene and his son, LIAM, watch. Gene juggles his fussy, eight month old grandson. LIAM (cont'd) She have any of her own? (Gene shoots him a look) What? It's never too late to start. Liam's enjoying himself but Gene doesn't take the bait.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Think you and Susan could get away for a week in June? We're renting a house out on Stonewall Beach.

dialogues.speaker: LIAM
dialogues.text: June? Maybe... (changing the subject) You keeping busy?

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: I've been asked to join a couple of boards. Dynex, Procar.

dialogues.speaker: LIAM
dialogues.text: You going to do it?

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: I don't know, thought of sitting around a conference room slogging through revenue projections and quarterly earning reports makes me want to put a gun in my mouth. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “The Company Men" Shooting Draft Yellows 5/4/09 97.

dialogues.speaker: LIAM
dialogues.text: Why don't you start a consulting firm. That's what Bo Collins' dad did after he left Archer. He's making a killing.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: LIAM
dialogues.text: Sure, there's always somebody out there willing to pay an opinionated old bastard for some shitty advice. Gene smiles. Liam hesitates, suddenly uncomfortable. Then LIAM (cont‘d) You surprised they closed the shipyard?

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: LIAM
dialogues.text: Gloucester, saw it on MSNBC this morning. The news hits Gene hard but he doesn't want to let on.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: I hadn't heard. Gene stares off, lost. Then: GENE (cont’d) So what do you say, the Vineyard in June? (and) Your mother'll be okay with it. Liam gives his father a sideways look. After a beat:

dialogues.speaker: LIAM
dialogues.text: You two talking? (Gene doesn't answer) She's having a pretty rough time. Gene doesn't want to have this conversation, deflects.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Stonewall Beach?

dialogues.speaker: LIAM
dialogues.text: I may be in San Diego by June. Phifzer offered me Manager of Strategic Planning. Liam meant it as good news but his father's concerned. (CONTTNUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 116 117 “The Company Men" Shooting Draft Yellows 5/4/09 98.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: You've only been with Merck for a year.

dialogues.speaker: LIAM
dialogues.text: Jim Haskell's a VP out there now, he's asked me to join his team.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: You don't want to get a reputation for bouncing around. The baby's really fussing now, Liam takes him back.

dialogues.speaker: LIAM
dialogues.text: I'm not “bouncing around".

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: This would be your third job since Yale.

dialogues.speaker: LIAM
dialogues.text: It's an excellent opportunity.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: That's not the point.

dialogues.speaker: LIAM
dialogues.text: Time's have changed. Loyalty's out of fashion. Your company isn't looking out for you, it's every man for himself. (then) I won't ever have the job you had, Dad. Liam wanders off to help children hunt eggs. Off Gene -- CuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: ROXBURY HOUSE
dialogues.text: Bobby pulls up in his used Camry, tugs on a Bruins cap, b now thoroughly scuffed, jacket dirty and ripped. Carries morning coffee run. Joins Jack unloading gear from the truck. Hands out Dunki Donuts coffees; one for Jack, one for Davey, one for --

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Where's Mike?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Got busted again. Jack starts for the front door, pissed. Bobby turns to Davey, lost in his usual haze of cigarette smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 117 118 119 "The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 99.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: Drunk and disorderly, assault, managed to take a swing at a cop, too. Davey follows Jack into the house. Bobby's stunned, * arrested? Jack reappears in the doorway, surly.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You still have that tool belt?

dialogues.speaker: THIRD FLOOR
dialogues.text: Bobby's tool belt hangs awkwardly from his hip as he nail furring strips onto studs around a fireplace. It's tricky the strips he's already nailed are crooked. The sound of NAIL GUNS somewhere else in the house. He's working alone Nails another one up. It splits, ugly. Picks up the next strip, fits it into place. Nails one end. Moves to the other end. Shit, it's a couple inches short of the stud.

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: Jesus... Davey's in the door. Lighting a new cigarette off the but of the last. Bobby's embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I thought I marked it right. Davey yanks the strip off in one motion. *

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: You don't want Jack seeing that shit. Measures it quickly. Pulls a pencil from behind his ear, writes the length on the wall. Measures it a second time. DAVEY (cont'd) * Measure twice, cut once. Jams his carpenters pencil behind Bobby's ear, goes. CuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: THIRD FLOOR
dialogues.text: Bobby nails up the last strip. Where he started still loo bad, but the rest is okay. He steps back, pleased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 100.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You finally done? Jack enters with Davey, grimaces, shakes his head. * JACK (cont'd) Christ, that is ugly. Starts back out. Bobby calls after him.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: If we're shorthanded, I know somebody who could use a job.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Hope he isn't slower than you. Jack goes. Davey's surveying Bobby's work. Nods, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: ROXBURY HOUSE
dialogues.text: The large pile of plywood, and... Danny. Hoisting up piec of sheet, carrying them over his head into the --

dialogues.speaker: ROXBURY HOUSE 121
dialogues.text: Up the stairs, heading for the second floor. Jack, Davey Bobby are out on the beams, nail-gunning the plywood shee in place. Jack sings along:

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: It's another tequila sunrise... Bobby comes gingerly across the beams to meet Danny and d the plywood into place for Davey to nail. *

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Jesus, he ever sing on key?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gene makes his way down the street, looking for something Stops. Heads into -- *  “The Company Men" Shooting Draft Goldenrod 5/15/09 101.

dialogues.speaker: THE ELBOW ROOM
dialogues.text: Gene waits for his eyes to adjust to the interior gloom. Phil's at Gene sits the bar.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: What're you doing?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Getting drunk. next to him.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: I called over to outplacement, see if you wanted to have lunch. They said you haven't been coming in much lately.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Oh yeah?

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Couple of weeks now.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: No kidding. (and) I_ drove out to Gloucester yesterday. Place is a fucking ghost town. Phil drains his drink, motions for another. The bartender gaunters over. Gene waves her off.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Why don't you let me drive you home?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Can't go home. Lorna doesn't want the neighbors to know I got fired so I can't show up until after six. Makes me haul my briefcase back and forth, too. They sit there for awhile. Finally: PHIL (cont'd) You see the Journal this morning? Listed how much CEOs made last year. Know who was seventeenth on the list? James Salinger, GTX. Twenty-two million in salary and bonuses. Gene nods, he saw it. Then: 122

dialogues.speaker: CCONTTNURN
dialogues.text: "The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 102.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Want to go to the movies? (Phil looks up, what?) Catch a matinee. They must still have Matinees. Get a bucket of popcorn, couple of those big Cokes. Phil grins in spite of himself. *

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY'S PARENTS' KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Bobby's mother Fran makes dinner as Carson sets the table Bobby enters through the back, lugging his tools and ther

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: Hi, Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Hello, beautiful. He picks her up, swings her around. Fran's grinning at hi BOBBY (cont'd) What're you smiling about?

dialogues.speaker: FRAN
dialogues.text: A man called today from Chicago. She finds a message on the counter by the phone, hands it him. Bobby stares at it as she continues. FRAN (CONT'D) (cont'd) A Fred Munder. Said he was impressed by your resume, asked you to call. (the clock) It's not quite five in Chicago.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY'S OLD BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Bobby's in the jammed closet, going through his clothes, packing a bag. Maggie leans on the dresser behind him.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: He's a headhunter.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I thought the job was in Boston? She's concerned, he knows why. (CONTTNURD )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 124 125 126 127 128 129 130 131 “The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 103.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: It is. I'll fly coach, stay at Motel 6. They're looking for a VP of Sales with extensive experience in transportation marketing. That's me. This is my job.

dialogues.speaker: MOTEL ROOM
dialogues.text: The bedside clock reads "4:19", but Bobby's wide awake. Looks at it, frustrated. Gives up. Swings out of bed.

dialogues.speaker: SAME
dialogues.text: It's still dark outside. Bobby's doing push-ups. Sit-ups.

dialogues.speaker: BATHROOM 127
dialogues.text: He shaves carefully. The in-room coffee pot percolating beside him on the sink top. Quietly, to himself, he chant

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I...will...win. Why? I'1l show you why... Because I have... Faith...courage...enthusiasm...

dialogues.speaker: MOTEL ROOM 128
dialogues.text: It's finally light out. He's in boxers, ironing his white shirt. Pulls it on, starts to tie his tie in the mirror. Hesitates for a moment. Remembers how. Smiles.

dialogues.speaker: SAME
dialogues.text: He sits on the edge of the bed fully, impeccably, dressed Waiting, looks at his watch. It's still too early to leav

dialogues.speaker: MICHIGAN AVENUE 130
dialogues.text: He walks down the crowded street on a bright spring day. Looking for an address. Finds it. Stares up at the marble skyscraper rising fifty stories above him. Smiles, pushes his way through the bra and glass doors.

dialogues.speaker: NORVELL, VANDER
dialogues.text: All polished teak and green granite. Makes his way to the attractive receptionist behind an impressive desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "~The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 104.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Robert Walker to see Fredrick Munder. The receptionist looks up.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: You have an appointment?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Yes, for ten.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: If you'd like to have a seat, I'll let his office know that you're here. Bobby nods. Heads for the waiting area. Orchids in a pot, soft butternut suede sofas, new Architectural Digest and Street Journals on the coffee table. He sits, leafs nervously through a Forbes. Too anxious to really focus.

dialogues.speaker: NEFELD
dialogues.text: Mr. Walker...? A pleasant, middle-aged woman in a nice suit, carrying a book. She seems concerned, confused. He stands. NEFELD (cont'd) I'm Jane Nefeld, Mr. Munder's assistant. You say you have an appointment?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Yes. At ten.

dialogues.speaker: NEFELD
dialogues.text: I don't see it... Uh-oh. She opens the large appointment book, checking.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I made it with Mr. Munder myself. She's looking, trying. BOBBY (cont'd) Friday at ten. We spoke two days ago.

dialogues.speaker: NEFELD
dialogues.text: Oh my...He has you down for next Friday. The seventeenth... A beat. Bobby tries to remain composed.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Next Friday? (CONTTNUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 131 132 133 “The Company Men" Shooting Draft Pinks 4/13/09 105.

dialogues.speaker: NEFELD
dialogues.text: (showing him) Yes. At ten. There it is. (smiles) Can you come back next week?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I flew in from Boston.

dialogues.speaker: NEFELD
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: If he's unavailable now, I can wait. Or I could come back this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: NEFELD
dialogues.text: Mr. Munder's in Dallas on business, he won't be back until next Wednesday.

dialogues.speaker: MICHIGAN AVENUE
dialogues.text: Bobby steps back out onto the street. The sidewalk is bus with business men and women, carrying briefcases, talking cell phones, checking Blackberries and Iphones, rushing f meetings and sales presentations. Towering office buildings rise up around him. Above the buildings, a deep blue sky, clouds drifting past unnotice Bobby stands there, the crowd parting, moving around him, avoiding. A man lost, surrendering. He stands there defeated for a long beat. Then reaches fo his tie, pulls it off, and walks away. Melting into the anonymous, crowded sidewalks of a city at work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilcox comes down the stairs, heels striking wooden steps she descends. Suit, briefcase tucked under one arm. Steps into the kitchen, slows at the sight of Gene parked the table, reading the newspaper. A mug of coffee waits f (CONTTNUED)

dialogues.speaker: 134A
dialogues.text: “The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 106.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: her on the kitchen counter. She takes a beat, then turns, goes. The front door CLOSES. Off Gene, never looking back

dialogues.speaker: BU CASTLE DINING ROOM
dialogues.text: A beautiful panelled room. High ceilings, white linen, 19 century portraits. Phil waits at a table, nursing a drink He's been nursing it for a while.

dialogues.speaker: DYSERT
dialogues.text: Sorry I'm late. Dysert, the man we met at Salinger's banquet. DYSERT (cont'd) Got caught on a call.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: No problem, I got a drink. The waiter appears.

dialogues.speaker: DYSERT
dialogues.text: Looks good, I'll have what he's having. (the waiter starts off) Hang on. You know what you want? (doesn't wait for an answer) I'll have the Cobb, no bacon.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Ah... rib eye, medium-rare, with fries.

dialogues.speaker: DYSERT
dialogues.text: Sorry to rush things, I've got to be back for a staff meeting at one-thirty. Phil smiles thinly. Guy shows up late, has to leave early

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: How're things at Betcher?

dialogues.speaker: DYSERT
dialogues.text: Ah...Germans's are giving us fits. You look great, you losing weight?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, well, dying my hair. And we realize, yeah. That's it. Okay... (CONTTNURED ¥

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 106A.

dialogues.speaker: DYSERT
dialogues.text: So how are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Fine, sending out a lot of resumes.

dialogues.speaker: DYSERT
dialogues.text: You're lucky to be out of it.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Word on the street is you're looking for a foreign sales exec.

dialogues.speaker: DYSERT
dialogues.text: You have someone to recommend?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Yeah, me. Dysert stares at him, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: DYSERT
dialogues.text: It's international, all travel.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I have extensive overseas experience. DYSERT. I'm sure you do. ‘(a beat) You mind my asking how old are you, Phil? Phil laughs, tries to sound disarming.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Not worried I'll sue?

dialogues.speaker: DYSERT
dialogues.text: I wouldn't hire. anyone over thirty for that job. It's a killer. Out of the country five out of every. six weeks.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Travel's not a problem.

dialogues.speaker: DYSERT
dialogues.text: Why don't you cash it in? Shit, I would. Go lie on a beach.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I can't afford to go lie on a fucking beach. Dysert sizes him up. A long beat. (CONTTNURD )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: +e ee

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oe OF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 106B.

dialogues.speaker: DYSERT .
dialogues.text: I can't recommend you for the ‘job. They'd laugh me out of the office. (a friend) My father died at his desk, massive coronary, he was sixty-two. Enjoy your life while you still can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ee EE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 107.

dialogues.speaker: A DOORBELL 135
dialogues.text: RINGS in the deep darkness of a late hour. A light CLICKS in the hallway of --

dialogues.speaker: WILCOX'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: Wilcox pulls on her robe. Makes her way down the stairs t the front door. The bell RINGS again, she peers through t glass side panels, perplexed. Opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: WILCOX
dialogues.text: Lorna. ..? ' Phil's wife standing out in the cold, nearly hysterical

dialogues.speaker: LORNA
dialogues.text: Is Gene here? cur To:  “The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 108.

dialogues.speaker: A ROAD
dialogues.text: Gene's driving, looking, nursing a 7-11 coffee. Takes a right, pulls along a deserted side road. Slows. Ahead, a car is pulled to the side of the road on an embankment. Lights off, engine running, driver's side door open. Phil's hunting in the tall grass of the gravel shoulder. Dishevelled, coat laying in a heap on the car hood. Gene walks toward him. Phil rears back, throws the rock h just dug up in the direction of the glass office building the other side of the expansive parking lot below. The GT sign glows serenely from the upper corner of the top floo A beat. The rock CLATTERS harmlessly on the asphalt below miles away from doing any damage.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Lorna's pretty worried about you, has you wrapped around a tree somewhere. A pint bottle of Chivas stands lonely sentinel on Phil's hood. He finds another rock, turns it over in his hand, weighing. Rears back, flings it with a mighty GRUNT...

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Sons of bitches... His voice echoes in the small amphitheater formed by the embankment as the rock SKITTERS across the parking lot be

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: What're you doing? Digs another rock out of the ground. Releases it with a thundering GRUNT, slips in the gravel, almost falls.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Motherfuckers...! Gene watches the rock sail away into the night. Follows i arc with Phil. Closer, closer... it HITS the sidewalk in front of the building, scoots harmlessly into the bushes.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Tom Brady couldn't hit that building from here on his best day. Phil stares at the building, chest heaving with exertion.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Sarah's class is going to Italy. I write the check, I can't make the mortgage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 137 138 "The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 109.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Gene watches him for a beat, then finally, carefully:

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: I could -- Phil shakes his head, "no". After another moment:

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: You know the worst part? (a beat) The world didn't stop. The newspaper still came every morning, the automatic sprinklers went off at six. Jerry next door still washed his car every Sunday. (then) My life ended and nobody noticed. 137

dialogues.speaker: ROXBURY HOUSE
dialogues.text: Bobby's hanging lathe with a nail gun, moving faster. Row

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: after row of nicely spaced lathe. Danny sticks his head i

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Boss says it's quitting time. Bobby nails up the last furring strip. Disconnects the pressure hose from the gun, shuts the compressor down. Gathers his thermos, joins Danny and Davey on the stairs. The hallway below them now drywalled, plywood floor.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Where's Jack? Danny points up as he starts down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Still working. Come on, I'm buying.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: It's three-thirty, what's he doing? Davey slings his belt and an extension over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: Been working late, trying to make the completion deadline, get the bonus.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Why doesn't he have us stay and help?

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: Can't pay us. (CONTTNITED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 110.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: He could pay us out of the bonus.

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: He needs the bonus to break even. He underbid to get the job and keep us working through the winter. Davey goes. Bobby looks above, the oldies radio and the w whine of a circular saw ripping 2x6. Takes a beat, then turns away, heading for his car and home.

dialogues.speaker: SUBURBAN BOSTON SHOPPING CENTER
dialogues.text: Phil comes out of a drugstore headed for his car, passes Dunkin' Donuts, Mailboxes Etc., 7-11. Stops. A sign in th Papa Gino's window. "Help Wanted".

dialogues.speaker: PAPA GINO'S
dialogues.text: It's dark, slow. A teenager buses a dirty table. Another one replenishes the salad bar.

dialogues.speaker: KID
dialogues.text: May I help you, sir? A pimply kid behind the counter.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I saw the sign in the window.

dialogues.speaker: KID
dialogues.text: Our Pizza Lovers special?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Ah, no. Your Help Wanted sign. The kid looks at him oddly. A beat. Calls back.

dialogues.speaker: KID
dialogues.text: Mr. Lister... A man appears from in back. Clean cut, thirties, friendly

dialogues.speaker: LISTER
dialogues.text: Hi, can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I saw your sign. I'm looking for a job. The man tries not to show his shock. Smiles politely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 111.

dialogues.speaker: LISTER
dialogues.text: It's a delivery job. Nights.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: You have an application I can fill out? Lister pauses, not sure how to proceed.

dialogues.speaker: LISTER
dialogues.text: Most of my drivers are in high school, it only pays minimum wage.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: LISTER
dialogues.text: Sir, you don't want this job.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I've never had a ticket or an accident.

dialogues.speaker: LISTER
dialogues.text: I'm sure you're a good driver.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: I have excellent references. (Lister says nothing) You won't let me deliver pizzas?

dialogues.speaker: LISTER
dialogues.text: No, sir. I won't.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL'S KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Phil is at the sink, doing the dishes. Methodically scrap food into the trash, runs water over the plates before setting them into the dishwasher.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Daddy? His daughter Sarah has appeared beside him. She takes a beat, then carefully: SARAH (cont'd) Mrs. Taylor stopped me today. She said she hasn't gotten our check yet. Phil scraps another dish into the trash, doesn't look at SARAH (cont'd) I don't have to go, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 141 142 143 "The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 112.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: There must have been some kind of mix-up, I'll call the school in the morning. This conversation is heartbreaking for the both of them.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: It's okay, it's not big deal. I know things are kinda tight right now. She leans in, kisses him on the cheek, leaves. Phil drops his head. Then turns off the water, steps into the living room to follow her, but she's already disappearing upstai Stops. Sees Lorna's on the sofa, passed out. TV on, a win glass and half-~empty bottle of Merlot on the coffee tabl He stares at her for a moment. Walks back into the kitche Goes to the sink, takes the trash out from underneath.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL'S BACKYARD
dialogues.text: Steps out his back door with the bag of trash. Stands on porch. Lights a cigarette. A dog barks down the block. He takes a deep, satisfying drag, sets the butt on the po railing. Walks across the yard, heading for the cans besi the garage on the alley. Opens a lid, dumps the trash in. Looks around. Steps to the garage's side door, opens it. Steps inside. We stay outside, DRIFTING BACK INTO the yar Fluorescent lights BLINK on inside. We watch him moving inside, silhouetted in the dirty glas the window. A car PASSES in the alley. The cigarette he left on the railing GLOWS, it's ash threatening to fall. BANG! A single shotgun blast from inside the garage as -- Lorna's eyes blink open. What was that? As a CHORUS of neighborhood dogs begin to BARK, we -~ cuUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: CAMBRIDGE MEMORIAL PARK
dialogues.text: Overlooking the Charles and downtown Boston. The mourners walk away from a grave site, head for their cars. Lorna a Sarah at the front, comforted by family. Trailing her; Bobby and Maggie, Gene and Wilcox, Danny an Conal, their wives. Diane, Lake, Jane, Carol. Sunlight drifts down through the spring trees. (CONTTNURD 1)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 143 144 vv 145 “The Company Men" Shooting Draft Pinks 4/13/09 113.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Gene stops by his car. Looks across to find: Cynthia. Watching him.. She takes a beat. Then climbs into her c: He turns back to find Sally there, watching him blankly. Then moves off to greet her younger contemporaries. Gene watches Cynthia's car drive away, steps over to Bobby.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Can Maggie give Sally a ride home?

dialogues.speaker: GLOUCESTER SHIPYARDS
dialogues.text: Towering buildings of rusting steel and galvanized sheet metal. Silent cranes rise hundreds of feet into the clear wintery sky. Miles of cracked concrete piers jut out into the white-capped Atlantic. Tankers and cargo ships. Decommissioned destroyers and frigates. All bearing silent witness to a thousand passag through exotic waters. The ghosts of sailors lost and the men who built these mighty ships whistle through the rust rigging and the deserted buildings. And inside the empty, cavernous --

dialogues.speaker: MAIN ASSEMBLY BUILDING 145
dialogues.text: Gene walks with Bobby. The ceiling a hundred feet above, work floor fifty yards wide and e quarter of a mile long. The overhead cranes and scaffolding are silent, the sound a thousand men riveting and welding now only distant echo

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: -We used to make something here. Before we got lost in the paperwork. The Nevada was built here. The Montana. The center of the floor is a massive rollered V, standing ready for another launch that will never come. GENE (cont'd) We had a frigate up front once and a missile boat behind. Phil started here, in hull assembly. He was a scrawny little bastard. Fearless, he'd hang upside down on a bosun's chair seventy feet off the shop floor to weld an overhead seam, Christ. (then) Two thousand men per shift, three shifts (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: CCONTTNITED Y
dialogues.text: 145 146 "The Company Men" Shooting Draft Pinks 4/13/09 114.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: GENE (cont'd) aday. Six thousand men earned a fair wage in this room, fed their families, bought homes. Made enough to send their kids to college and buy a second car, Pigeons dart from beam to beam high above them. GENE (CONT'D) (cont'd) Building something they could see. A ship you could see and smell and touch. Men Khow their worth, knew who they were. He steps through the massive sea doors and out into ~-

dialogues.speaker: THE SUNLIGHT OF THE PIER 146
dialogues.text: The wind off the Atlantic rustles their hair, their ties.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: One day you're making fifty bucks, then five thousand, then five million. Gene stops at the edge of the water, looks out to the sea GENE (cont'd) You start with some crazy idea, take insane risks, make barely enough to feed your family, not a chance you're gonna succeed. Then all of a sudden you've got all these things and you're terrified of losing them. Stock options, and company jets. Vacation homes in the Bahamas. A container ship BLASTS it's horn, far out in the bay, heading to sea. Gene watches it's progress for a moment. GENE (cont'd) Truth is, I liked the five hundred doliar lunches and thousand dollar hotel rooms. (a eevecrni hi And now eve: ig I spent thirty years helping to build for myself and everybody else is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 147 148 “The Company Men” Shooting Draft Pinks 4/13/09 115.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY'S PARENTS' HOUSE
dialogues.text: Bobby climbs the stairs in his clothes from the funeral. is on somewhere below. ‘The bedroom door is open, Maggie inside at the desk she's taken over to use as her vanity. He stops in the open door, watching her evening ritual. S wears an old T-shirt of his, lies lotion to her bare legs She sees him in the mirror, smiles softly.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: For everything. For letting you down.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You haven't let me down.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Sure I have.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You were never here before. (then) And now you are.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: (a beat/he starts to go) The dryer vent's clogged again, I told my Mom I'd take a look.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: He stops, she stands, walks to him, takes his hand. MAGGIE (cont'd) It can wait. Pulls him into the room, closing the door behind them as

dialogues.speaker: NEW GTX CORPORATE HEADQUARTERS ENTRANCE
dialogues.text: A chauffeured car pulls into the entrance. Salinger climb out of the back, starts for the doors. Hello, Jim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “The Company Men" Shooting Draft Buffs 5/28/09 116.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Gene's waiting by the main doors. Salinger stops. They stare at each other, unsure of what comes next.

dialogues.speaker: SALINGER
dialogues.text: How have you been, Gene?

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Kind of shitty. I was recently fired by my best friend. {Salinger doesn't respond) We missed you at the funeral.

dialogues.speaker: SALINGER
dialogues.text: I was sorry to hear about Phil, how's Lorna holding up? Gene doesn't honor that with an answer, looks off. Then:

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: We built something together here, Jim. With these people. It wasn't just you and it wasn't just me. It was all of us.

dialogues.speaker: SALINGER
dialogues.text: They got a paycheck every week, medical care if they got sick, disability if they got hurt. This is a business, not a charity.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: You made twenty-two million last year. These people have lost their homes, their marriages, the respect of their children.

dialogues.speaker: SALINGER
dialogues.text: We did what the market required of us to survive!

dialogues.speaker: CCONTTNIED
dialogues.text: 148 “The Company Men" Shooting Draft Buffs 5/28/09 117.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Gene looks off, doesn't answer. After a beat: SALINGER (cont'd) The Board accepted Allied’s bid last night. Thirty-nine billion at 97 a share. They've asked me to stay on for a few months to help with the transition.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: +..I'm sorry. Gene means it. But Salinger refuses to accept his concern

dialogues.speaker: SALINGER
dialogues.text: Don't be, my shares are worth six hundred million.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: (after a moment) Congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: SALINGER
dialogues.text: How much are your shares worth now? Twenty million? Thirty? Gene doesn't answer. Salinger smiles, starts to go. SALINGER (cont'd) I have to get to work.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Jim, (Salinger stops) We never worked for the stockholders, we worked for ourselves. We got fat and the people who trusted us to look out for them got run over. They deserved better. Salinger turns, disappears into the building. Off Gene, watching him go we ~-

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 149 150 151 “The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 118.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gene turns the Aston into the drive that leads to his hou The garage door opens to REVEAL Cynthia's Mercedes, the varnished concrete floor, and his empty parking spot. He hesitates, then slowly pulls the Aston into the garage

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks to the door. Starts to slip his key into the loc Stops. Hesitates. Turns to go. * Cynthia opens the door. Stands there, silent. He doesn't know what to say. She considers him for an agonizing beat. Then opens the d wider to let him in. As he disappears inside, off Cynthia cUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: THE WALKER'S BACKYARD
dialogues.text: Bobby and Drew are up in a tree, Carson on the ground, * playing. They're hammering old boards, nails. Building a tree house in the branches.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Hold it there. He pounds the nail in a couple of inches, leaving some he BOBBY (cont'd) You sink it. Don't choke up on the handle, you'll get a better swing. Drew smashes it in the rest of the way. BOBBY (cont'd) We lay another 2x4 across there and we'll be ready to drop in the floor.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Bobby...? Maggie's down on the ground, shielding her eyes against t sun to look up into the tree. MAGGIE (cont'd) You've got a call. A Frederick Munder's office from Chicago? Bobby stares down from the tree. Doesn't move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 151 152 153 154 "The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 119.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: MAGGIE (cont'd) She said it was important. Bobby hands Drew his hammer, drops down onto the 2x4s nai into the tree trunk for a ladder,

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Nail in some more sixteen sinkers. Jumps down to the lawn beside Maggie. Looks to the house doesn't move.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Well, go on. They're waiting. He walks at first, then jogs across the yard. Bounds up t stairs to the porch and disappears inside. Off Maggie we

dialogues.speaker: ROXBURY HOUSE
dialogues.text: Bobby pulls his car into the muddy yard, there's tar pape down on the roof, stacks of shingles waiting in the dirt. Bobby climbs out, swings his tool belt over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: ROXBURY HOUSE ENTRANCE HALLWAY 153
dialogues.text: Bobby enters, carrying a couple of coffees. Rough electri in, trim. Bobby stops, listens, a nail gun echo upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: THE ROOF 154
dialogues.text: Jack's laying down roofing shingles, Allman Brothers on l on the radio. Bobby appears at the top of the ladder, cli up onto the roof with the two coffees.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Working Sundays now? Jack stops, turns. Caught. Bobby offers him a coffee. BOBBY (cont'd) Diedre says you've been out here every weekend. How much money you losing?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: A bit.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Because of me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “The Company Men" Shooting Draft Pinks 4/13/09 120.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Sometimes I'm up, sometimes I'm down. It all works out in the end. These guys still aren't friends and never will be, but there's now a growing respect.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: A guy called me today, offered me a job.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Yeah? Decent pay?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Eighty a year.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Thousand? Jack shakes his head, picks up his Skill saw to cut.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: It's about half what I used to make.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: The world's a fucked-up place. Bobby watches as Jack RIPS the saw through a board loudly

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Actually, I was thinking maybe I'd keep working for you. (Jack stares at him) I used to be afraid all the time, you know? The quarterly sales reports, the young guys coming up. Afraid I was going to lose an account or somebody was going to get ahead of me.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Can I be honest with you, Bobby? Take the job, you're a terrible carpenter. Bobby laughs, he's not hurt. DANNY. Christ, can't they make these damn things any lighter? Danny's appeared at the top of the ladder, wrestling a bu of shingles up onto the roof with a THUD. Jack stares at Bobby. Danny climbs up onto the roof, straightens his bac

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY'S PARENTS' HOUSE AND ALLEY
dialogues.text: Bobby parks in the alley beside the garage. Climbs out wi his tools, tired, dirty. Drew's ghosting | in the alley, working on his jumper on Bobby's old. rusted rim nailed u over the garage. Makes one. Bobby applauds.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: You want to play? BOBBY . Gotta make a call. Maybe later, okay? Drew nods, not surprised, turns back to his game. Bobby takes a few steps toward the gate, then stops. Turns back

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 156 "The Company Men" Shooting Draft 3/30/09 123.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: watches Drew dribble, take another shot. Looks to the hou again, then drops his tools. CLAPS for the ball. BOBBY (cont'd) Pass it in. Drew looks up, what? His father CLAPS again. Drew passes him the ball. Bobby dribbles, puts a move on his son, but the kid picks it up, defends. Bobby fakes left, goes righ hard, knocks Drew backwards onto his ass on the asphalt. Takes the lay-up. Recovers the ball. Drew stares up at his Dad. Shit. But Bobby offers no apology, extends a hand to his still startled son. BOBBY (cont'd) First one to eleven? Drew doesn't take the offered hand. Stands on his own, re to rumble. Bobby grins, pops the ball to a determined Dre WE PULL SLOWLY AWAY as Drew comes at his father hard, one way, then the other. No mercy. Bobby laughs, Drew scoots around him fast in the fading afternoon light of the alle stops short. Bobby falls for it, Drew takes the open jump Drew grins as the ball falls in and we --
